author: @retros.pection
text:
this is very risky, a team of new indian devs trying to make such a game, trying to bring indian myth to light
i want to see it succeed, but
it's very very rough right now, so i hope you don‚Äôt deny the criticisms coming your way

the animations, first up, very clunky, not impactful at all
sound design doesn‚Äôt help either
character movement looks like it‚Äôs trying to copy bmwk, but it‚Äôs just not there yet
the riposte animation too, yeah, doesn‚Äôt look great
the boss just seemed to repeat attacks too, which isn't great

art direction, the environment looks good in parts, but some elements feel inconsistent
colors are weird, washed out in one place, oversaturated in another
atmosphere/ambience is just... missing
level design too, kind of lackluster

voice acting? needs heavy work

i can‚Äôt offer any solutions, i‚Äôm not a dev (yet) but i‚Äôve been playing games since forever,
and ngl, i wouldn‚Äôt enjoy what i‚Äôm seeing in the alpha right now
hoping it evolves from here, into an actual good game
props to the devs, goodluck

author: @tanishgehlot
text:
A MESSAGE FROM INDIAN HARDCORE GAMING COMMUNITY

-  focus on hardcore gamers as we are the actual people who will spend their money to play this game
-  graphic quality is important but in the end its all about gameplay
-  many indian games dont focuses on side quests or small missions apart from main story line which makes  a good game a great one
- game optimization is all that lacks in  indie games we dont want our game to be laggy and choppy 
- we are gamers who dont go outside in the real world, so we love to explore the in game world, if the game boundaries are too short they ruin the experience
- PLS consider the user of the game SMART , many indian games thinks we gamers are not smart enough and they make the game easy and even a simple common sense mission they treat user that they know nothing
   
conclusion
- graphic good but gameplay great
- we can wait for few years but dont waste our money on unfinished product 
- what we like in games - explore, solve puzzles by ourselves even if it is hard, some side quests or achievements apart from main story line or may be some easter egg that is way hard to find
- INDIA is in our heart, a game cant make us more patriotic let it be a game rather than a product with an indian flag on it

WE BELEIVE IN YOU DONT BREAK OUR TRUST LIKE OTHERS DID

author: @ParikritKoirala
text:
Just a suggestion
1) Optimization is the most important thing. Even looking at the trailer it feels quite choppy. 
2) that's amazing that you and your people are working hard for this but  the game needs to well managed I guess working only 1-2 years on triple A games and publishing it is not worth it.  It looks great but find some ideas and take some time to make things even better for a great experience
3) looking at the trailer chatecter model looks quite unrealistic. Especially in combat where blood scatters in unrealistic way. Like adding wounds on damaged ones would make it lot more better 
4)  while looking the facial movement features should be added like in combat chatecter should look aggressive doing so will make the game even more immersive. 
5) that's great you and your team has put lot of efforts but adding different combat styles and finishing move would be great 
 
These are my perspective and some suggestion hope you find this well ‚ù§‚ù§

author: @HarshitBahri
text:
A major issue with Black Myth: Wukong was its optimization, largely due to being developed on Unreal Engine 5. This engine, while powerful, demands high-end hardware, which means the game requires expensive graphics cards and powerful PCs to run smoothly.

The game saw most of its sales from China, which makes sense given the cultural connection and the story‚Äôs roots in Journey to the West.

However, considering that the majority of Indian gamers are on mobile platforms and can‚Äôt afford a PS5 or a high-end gaming PC, this approach indirectly excludes a large portion of potential players‚Äîespecially in regions like India‚Äîjust for the sake of graphical realism.

Good work though ‚ù§Ô∏è

author: @utkarshmishra7574
text:
Instead of diving straight into full-blown AA or AAA Souls-like games, Indian studios should focus on creating smaller, well-polished titles. This approach would help them gain valuable experience in game development, distribution, and finances, otherwise Indian games will never take off.

And what is this obsession of cringe-worthy, Bollywood-style characters and stereotypical storytelling. It‚Äôs time to break free from these clich√©s and start creating original, thought-provoking content that reflects creativity and innovation rather than tired tropes.

author: @akhileshwar833
text:
Hat's off to you. As someone wrote, make for the world, not for India. 
A bit of caution: While we do have mythologies, it is also important to respect people's beliefs and not trivialize things just for making entertainment for the world. It's fine to take inspiration from mythologies but using characters should be done cautiously and respectfully. It is better not to put any gods in the game. Like we don't want a situation where a god like thor is having romance.  Also, if it is mythology inspired, then it is encouraged to also make it meaningful.  

As for the game itself, i would say make it more than just India's souls-like. It should have some memorable features that are not in any Souls game but people enjoy that a lot. Idk, maybe aerial fights or flying. Maybe include controllable spatial and time powers. And make the world more alive where not everyone wants to attack you lol. Include things like cows maybe. And please don't get restricted due to 'India's first soul-like': it's just about being a but more creative and having a bit more ideas, which can elevate the game to a whole new level. And since it is based in India, an lot of ancient Indian weapons can be included which i am sure you are including. Even mythological weapons like Sudarshan chakra can be cool. You can also add things like temples, where fight is forbidden, giving respect can unlock some powers or heal and there could be some teachings there as well. As in sleeping dogs, in buddhist shrines, lighting incense increases health bar. In the end, i wohld again emphasize, do not be constrained by the term Souls-like. U could create situations where we are traveling on a ship and are fighting in a ship, it's not one vs all situation but there can be necessary ncp allies as well.

author: @krishnatagore5750
text:
I appreciate that Indian games are coming. But this is just sekiro rip off with indian assets. Its not wrong to take inspiration from another game but should not copy the whole thing exactly. Like shrine as a checkpoint, sword seems like katana movement, death blow looks like owls mikiri counter, the word appearing on screen when a serious attack is coming, posture bar etc etc. Black myth handled the game mechanics properly to get a souls like feel. Here I am pointing about only game mechanics not graphics.
If you want to stand out in the world, honestly with this its impossible. You need to reformulate the game mechanics again to make it different from other games. Even top tier graphic games fail due to poor game mechanics. I am not blaming about graphics which I can understand with small team you are building but you also need to change the art style to be good. But biggest priority should be game mechanics improvement. Honestly you will receive a lot of hate from hard core fans of souls games. The people in comment section are not aware of this and hence supporting. I have no right to judge you, but I am suggesting you because I want Indian gaming industry to thrive and this game at beta stage. So it can still be improved . Wish you all the best!!

author: @aaritranjanmaity5624
text:
I will come with this criticism. This game 'feels" like ass. If graphics were the only thing that mattered then games like ultrakill would not have been so critically acclaimed. You are making a game not a movie, so focus on the gameplay mechanic first. Its choppy, sloppy, and doesn't feel fun. It's like those old phone game, space shooter and stuff, but with better graphics. 

Heres what I suggest, for player, make his swings sharp. By that I mean delete some frames in his animation so the swing of the weapon feels like a gun shot. To make it seem more powerful, some particle effects on hit can work. In souls like, victory over enemies must feel earned. So instead, try making enemies with a non subtle variety of attacks, and give them some characteristics. 
By characteristics, I mean like imagine two different kind of enemies, a heavy guy and a light guy. Heavy guy's attack will be telegraphed, but he will attack strong. His defense will be High as well, and some change in sound effects may do the trick while fighting him (A feedback mechanism will be good too). The light guy will fight fast and will drain your hp if you are not quick enough. Do the same thing with his attacks as you did with the player. Heres another thing.
I mean seriously, I can't really anymore more about this, but it feels like a 3d project rather than, well, a 'game'.

author: @iamvanshikapandey
text:
This is a dream come true. As a kid, I used to hope there was a game which accurately portrayed India a game which highlighted our rich cultures, beautiful landscapes, varied environments, and spectacular natural beauty. A game which fulfills everything from snow-covered mountains to green plains, clean rivers, and vast expanse of greens. It does not have to be 100% realistic to the world this can be a game of fun and creativity. A good story, breathtaking graphics, and a lively atmosphere would make it unforgettable.

I recall thinking as a child, 'I will create a game that is famous throughout the world for its culture and beauty,' but I never quite reached it. To see this finally coming to fruition is just so fulfilling. Good luck to your team, I hope you make something truly amazing. Make this game a masterpiece!

author: @hectera
text:
It is deeply disappointing when a piece of media chooses to represent India solely through the lens of poverty, especially by showcasing slums as the primary visual identity. India is a nation of vast diversity, rich culture, and breathtaking landscapes‚Äîfrom the snow-capped Himalayas and lush backwaters of Kerala to the architectural marvels of Rajasthan and the vibrant skylines of modern cities like Bengaluru and Mumbai. Reducing this incredible country to a single stereotype is not only lazy storytelling, but also deeply disrespectful to the millions who take pride in their heritage and progress.

Such representation fuels the global misconception that India equals poverty, ignoring the fact that the nation is also home to one of the world‚Äôs fastest-growing economies, a booming tech industry, and a youthful, innovative population. Developers and content creators have a responsibility to portray cultures with depth and nuance‚Äînot with tired clich√©s. While it‚Äôs true that every country has its struggles, it‚Äôs unfair to highlight only the flaws while ignoring the beauty, resilience, and brilliance that define its people. It's time for the world to see India beyond the slums, and recognize the elegance, energy, and excellence it truly embodies.

author: @tejjm4263
text:
Hey Varun and team,

I‚Äôve been playing games since I was a kid ‚Äî I‚Äôm 28 now ‚Äî and recently I played Ghost of Tsushima. In the gameplay you showed there were a few things I felt were missing, especially when it came to the sound design.

During combat with mid-tier or low-tier enemies, the sounds and character dialogues didn‚Äôt feel very immersive. It lacked that emotional pull or intensity. Also, the world around you should feel alive even when you‚Äôre just moving through it. Ghost of Tsushima does a good job with ambient sounds like rustling grass, birds chirping, foxes, and some NPC interactions. The Witcher 3 or Red Dead Redemption 2, those NPCs and their interactions felt much more immersive and dynamic.

All the best! Looking forward to play this!

author: @swlchl
text: Let me preface this by saying I'm *so* glad someone's decided to take India a step forward into the gaming industry, and the effort you and your team have put into this is undeniable... but at least in its current state, from what was shown in the trailer, the game's mechanics seem *very* derivative of Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice, to the point of being a borderline clone, and I find it disheartening that despite putting an incredible amount of effort into the art, assets and world, you've taken such a derivative approach to your gameplay. From the mechanics to even the animations and indicators, *everything* about the combat shown in that trailer looks like it was reskinned from Sekiro, and for the first AAA game from India to be a Sekiro reskin really doesn't sit right with me... I hope you can still take the game in a different direction because I'm really excited about its prospect, but this is *not* the way to go about designing your core systems.

author: @barunmajumdar679
text:
I have some feedback to share‚Äîboth the highlights and the areas that could use improvement.
The Good

 ‚Äì First off, congratulations on taking on such an ambitious project. Many teams opt for smaller-scale titles, but you‚Äôve tackled something far more substantial‚Äîand that‚Äôs truly commendable.

‚Äì The visuals are gorgeous, and it‚Äôs clear the art team has poured their hearts into achieving this level of polish.

 ‚ÄìThe Movement Looks nice.

The Bad
Disclaimer: I‚Äôm an aspiring game dev as well with far less experience than your team; my thoughts come purely from a player/consumer perspective.

 ‚ÄìGameplay, gameplay, gameplay. If you‚Äôre marketing this as a ‚ÄúSouls‚Äëlike,‚Äù the combat needs to feel engaging, challenging, and‚Äîyes‚Äîpunishing. You‚Äôve cited Sekiro as inspiration, which means we need fast-paced, precise, and fluid combat mechanics. Right now, aside from the Kshudita Asura (which I genuinely enjoyed), most fights feel generic and lacklustre‚Äîalmost like a watered-down imitation. I hope I‚Äôm proven wrong at launch, but at present, it doesn‚Äôt feel as refined as Sekiro or Lies of P, both of which nail that ‚Äúflow state‚Äù of combat.

 ‚ÄìSetting suggestion (personal preference): The city-and-slum aesthetic doesn‚Äôt quite resonate with the epic, mythic tone you seem to be aiming for. My suggestion would be to lean into a world inspired by classical Indian culture and history‚Äîthink rural landscapes, grand raja/maharaja‚Äìera architecture, and tasteful modern touches (like period‚Äëinspired firearms). That way, the Ramayana‚Äëinspired narrative can truly shine without feeling out of place.

Again, these are just my thoughts‚Äîyou‚Äôve already achieved a lot, and I sincerely hope the final game not only meets but exceeds these expectations!

author: @AshwinPrakash-e4f
text:
I'm really happy and concerned that you are stepping into a very risky zone in the indian market. I know this is an alpha, but these are my thoughts:
1) The character's leg animation, I loved it mostly.
2) The dirt interactions on the ground.
3) The overall setting and background looks promising 

Now to the imp parts.
1) The name of game, ui, hud look way too generic. The name could be something very imdicative of the narration or character, if you think of it the name suites many fantasy AAA games..where a power is unleashed. The Ui should be such which prompts to player to start the game. It should be a part of the story. The hud, i think it's overly being indianized, just to be indian, a national pride is awesome but shouldn't overshadow the game. As in an american game or a chinese game wont shout chinese out. So keep some things like the hud minimalistic yet original to the game.
2) If the gameplay showcased is an actual part of the story, then it's lackluster, as in..there's not much context..im pretty sure there's more to it! 
3) The charater movements and attacks shouldn't be just a button click and animate..it should feel cohesive. 
4) Character eye contact and expressions should be improved (I liked that giant mans face after that show off, excellent for an alpha of the build)

I'll edit if I notice more, full support. Nail it. 
Don't just creat a fantasic product but also do fantastic marketing to get it put there. Do large collabs, celebs, actors...if both aspects are in place, I'm sure you'll nail it. Looking forward to play this game‚ù£Ô∏è

author: @shubharthidasgupta25
text:
Just like everyone else, the first order of things is a big congratulations. You are doing a great job. But, I wanted to highlight a small thing, and perhaps a different perspective/take.

- The game looks great. But it won't matter much if the performance is not that good. Whatever happens, the game should run consistently well and bug-free at 60fps+. That would be my personal number one priority, even over the graphics. I am prepared to play a game with mediocre graphics if it has a good and engaging story and runs wells. It may be early days, but the first look and gameplay did not look so smooth. The animations look jittery, missing frames, etc. I am sure with the crew you have those will not be overlooked. Hopefully later on with more polish the game FEELS good, not just look good. MOBAs are a good example of this.

- The story HAS to be engaging. It can be a short 10-15 hour story, but it has to hook the players till the end. Even if it means less side quests and collectibles. Sifu is a great example of a brilliantly done short game.

Best of luck to you guys and you are doing an awesome job. Keep up the good work!

author: @ADI-xp4qe
text:
As a 3D artist myself I wanted to share few thoughts let me know if they are constructive. 
To start off, good job with putting the efforts, i think things are in right direction but can be pushed further 
So, firstly i think it's important to understand what your game is aiming towards gameplay or narrative. Great games have a balance of both but it's subjective at the same time, like detroit is a great narrative based game while doom has crazy good gameplay. So from that point of view I feel the vision is missing from the trailer. Again you can argue we have story through art and have gameplay. But, I think narrative should not be spoonfed to the audience on a primary level it's fine but you can always aim for complexity to get better results. 
My suggestion talk or hire gameplay designers and narrative designers who have great experience in this domain and have a vision what do you want to showcase. It doesn't have to be rocket science, just proper vision towards the goal. 
Second, problem with photogrammetry from an artistic standpoint. While it's great that you have used scans to recreate this whole settings, there are few issues with it. 1st you can't use unreals PBR to full potential because most of the data is borrowed from real life and they act as buffer to enhance the artistic aspects. So, in short i think it's important to aim for less is more. 
Second, there was a wide contrast between the characters the props and environment, from a style pov. Which made things unrelated and inconsistent. 

I have showcased artistic feedback later because i understand the technical limitations and this being your first game i understand the sheer ignorance with development you guys will have and its great that you are on this endeavour to push things and our industry i 100% support this thing and looking forward to your progress.
And i believe you man you do listen to your audience, so I hope you go through this feedback too. 

Hope this helps
Goodluck üòä

author: @Its_frenzy_shorts
text:
Jo clips tumne dikhaye hain, woh thode realistic toh lag rahe hain, lekin natural bilkul nahi lagte. Aisa lag raha hai jaise random assets ko ek saath daal diya gaya ho bina proper composition ke ‚Äî pura 3D environment ek cluttered scene jaisa lag raha hai. Haan, tumne 3D scan technology use kiya hai, but models abhi bhi utne polished nahi lag rahe ki unhe ek high-quality ya so-called AAA game mein use kiya ja sake.

Animations bhi bilkul vibe ke saath match nahi kar rahe ‚Äî unmein polish ki kami hai aur woh kaafi unprofessional lag rahe hain. Overall movement aur transitions mein koi proper flow ya consistency nahi dikh raha.

Aur sabse important baat ‚Äî tumne ab tak gameplay mechanism ka ek bhi part dikhaya nahi hai. Jab tak woh clear nahi hota, tab tak hum game ke core experience ke baare mein kuch bol hi nahi sakte.

Thoda environment design refine karo, animations ko improve karo, aur gameplay ka thoda glimpse dikhana start karo ‚Äî tabhi log fair opinion de paayenge.

author: @xXApexPredator
text:
Congratulations on reaching this exciting stage with your game. Even in its early alpha build, it‚Äôs clear that a great deal of passion, creativity, and technical skill has gone into it. The foundation you‚Äôve laid shows strong potential.

As you move forward, I encourage you to focus deeply on gameplay, narrative depth, character responsiveness, and progression systems‚Äîthese are what truly define a memorable player experience.

There‚Äôs a unique opportunity here to ground the game in Indian culture and storytelling. Think Ghost of Tsushima‚Äîa game that thrived by staying authentic. This could be India‚Äôs Uncharted or Tomb Raider: cinematic, tightly designed, and rooted in local heritage. I‚Äôd recommend avoiding an open-world format and instead crafting a refined, narrative-driven journey.

Take the time you need to polish it‚Äîquality outlasts deadlines. You‚Äôre on the right path. Keep pushing‚Äîthis could be something truly special.

author: @aliveoceans
text:
The game looks visually stunning and the gameplay seems quite engaging‚Äîgreat work to the team! üëè However, I‚Äôd like to share a serious concern about the portrayal of the final villain. His appearance, especially with the tilak and vibhuti (sacred ash) on his forehead, strongly resembles that of a Hindu priest or devotee.

I understand the intention might be to depict a Ravana-like character, but in reality, these symbols are worn by countless peaceful and devout Hindus as part of their spiritual practice. Using them to represent evil risks promoting harmful stereotypes.

Frankly, if this were done by someone unfamiliar with Indian culture‚Äîsay, a foreign developer‚Äîit might be seen as ignorance, misunderstanding, or even bias. But when something like this is created by Indians, in India, it becomes deeply disappointing and shameful. Our own creators should know better than to misrepresent sacred traditions for dramatic effect.

I hope future portrayals will handle cultural and religious symbolism more responsibly. Looking forward to seeing how the game evolves.

(One of my most favorite games of all time though, so I was equally shocked and happy when the 'sword clash' sounded pretty familiar! üòÇ) 
The environment looks Uncharted 4 remastered level (which is amazing!), though the animations sure look ps2 level (no offense, I know it's a very early build), guess it'll take atleast 2 years to polish all that out. üòÖ
Though, I would really prefer if you take all the time you guys require to polish it like a diamond, instead of hurrying and putting like out all those buggy, glitchy, abominations we were getting from real 3A studios üòÇ.

You guys are right... If you can pull this off, I can finally see other Indians getting a confidence boost, and who knows, maybe we'll get our own Soul's aside, Wukong or stellar blade by 2030?

author: @freakymousewithcig
text:
I see that your game is going towards the "souls-like" genre of games with the parrying, rest shrines, bosses and dodging. As a huge fan of souls-like games and having played various top-notch souls like games with probably the hardest difficulties, I want to recommend you a few things which I think will make the game much more souls-like!

1. Textures don't always mean everything! You can have the best graphics in the world but if the gameplay mechanics isn't on-par with the quality then what's the point? A major audience in India don't have very high-spec systems. In fact, I believe most play on laptops or computers they buy for study or college purposes. So please try to optimize the game enough so that it is smooth to run. After all, no souls-like game is enjoyable without a smooth fps.

2. The gameplay mechanics seem pretty lineant and impact-less. I mean, how can one deflect a giant-ass weapon without any struggle? It's as if the deflecting animation has just been copied and pasted everywhere without even tweaking it. Please make the deflection feel as if it packs a punch (like with audio effects, smooth recoil).

3. Some of the gameplay mechanics feel weird. How can one deflect bullets using a wide machete by just parrying it? The running animation feels as if its just been copied from Assassin's Creed. Why would there be a huge-ass "Sankat" warning message? Wouldnt it just make seeing the boss's moves harder? Instead why not just give it a small, minimal looking but noticeable skull icon or hindi letter etc (like that of Sekiro). The blood particles or parrying particles feel overly exxagerated. I would advice reducing the density of particles, making the radius smaller and the colour less brighter.

4. The lack of expressions are pretty noticeable. When a policeman notices some criminal, he makes that "OYE" or "IDHAR AA" expressions i.e the angry/annoyed emotions. The goons should have that cocky, egoistic emotions. The characters mechanics feel choppy and the expressions arent even there when he is choking that enemy in the first scene.

5. The "activate shrine" should cause the screen to go dark or some effects other than just idling on the screen. Also, please add some little details like when the big boss hits the ground, his weapon should leave a crater/hole. The HUD feels a bit wide (personal preferrence). You could make it thinner but more longer or minimalistic so that it doesnt interfere with the gameplay. Also, please try to include the beautiful landscapes of India as well and not just those slums or villages. By that I mean, the beautiful mountains or gardens or beaches etc which we have. The UI should be less brighter with the font having a darker coulour. (I feel that the yellow-red background makes the text harder to read in the inventory. Also, please include simpler terms for the various items to be found in the game. (I mean the sankskrit or pure-hindi terms might be hard to understand for the general audience.

As an Indian, I too feel proud that we are finally venturing into the game-developement space. From one Indian gamer to another, I found it necessary for me to make this comment since I dont want this project to not be excellent after all the hard-work and time you all have spent.

author: @thuneshkhairwar3726
text:
This project seems to be nothing more than an asset flip. It could be a marketing strategy, misleading advertising, or potentially a scam. I question whether they have truly dedicated effort to 70% of the game. If they have, where did the funding come from? The claim of eight months of development raises some doubts.

*Let's Discuss Mumbaiüèô Gulliesüõ£*

Mumbai Gullies is still in the development phase and is seeking financial backing to finalize the game.

Varun Mayya might emerge as the next Nikhil Malankar.

Fundingü§ëü§ëü§ë

He claims the game will be of high quality, yet sound design remains unaddressed, which requires significant investment.

It appears they may have hurriedly completed the game by reusing assets within a month to secure funding.

Hiring üôã‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èüôã‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Moreover, they have recruited talent from AAA companies, indicating they are aware of their worth. This could mean they are charging higher rates, akin to international developers.

The trailer showcases a vibrant Indian gully, but this is not reflected in the gameplay. Perhaps they should ask the 3D modelers to create renders based on references from Chanderi.

This perception contributes to why some foreigners view us Indians as scammers.

author: @xunchann
text:
5:30 Starting

As the game has maintained such high quality environment and realism in its surroundings I (not speaking for others) personally would expect  to see more things be logical and consistent, Some might say why am I expecting logics in game, games aren't real, things are very much made up in it. Then here is the timestamp 12:30 where Varun himself talks about how they care about little details like window, handle of auto and scooter & so, to fix the imperfections. When such little detail matters then I think battles and interaction of the character with other things should also have same consistency to make sense. I hope this comment is taken as constructive criticism because if devs are talking about quality and perfection I think as a user I have the ability to criticize about it as well.

6:20 The ground is wet and muddy, how come the character is running on a wet ground making no noise and sneaking up on enemy what sort of stealth is that? It would make more sense if enemy was more aggro and not just walking around with no sense of danger.

6:45 again if you look at the environment it is very much real looking, but the blood looks totally cartoonish as its some RPG game, painted on top of scene, you can pause your video around this timestamp and see how inconsistent things are.

8:51 The cutscene, finger of the boss enemy looks like noodles as it has no bones, too long and thin as compared to whole size of the boss enemy itself same for the other side of arm, looks deformed inconsistent size and shape 

Overall the map seems very narrow and small, 5-6 enemy after just few steps in game and then a boss fight?
If there was even 3-4 lines of story telling it would look and feel much better, hopefully in official teaser things will make more sense.

And now some brutal inputs, pehli baat toh I don't understand why all Indian devs or creators khudka product launch karke emotion selling kyu karte hai? Indian culture ko represent karna hai but aisa kya character ko dhoti dediya villains are some ruthless civilians and bad police men? and thoda religious Ramayana or Mahabharat ke story ki touch dedo or emotion selling hojayegi kisi god ke avatar ko showcase kardo kya hai ye sab no matter how high quality the game is made in what's the point of it when the same typical mistake continues which other industries failed to fix as well

author: @VinitR
text:
I really like what you presented, gameplay. Although the presentation could look more engaging if you have at least two speakers, makes the viewer feel part of the team.
One suggestion I have for your team: Take feedbacks with a grain of salt, so many people nag about a lot without understanding market research, what is trending, keywords a user would expect from a premise. E.g. the slums are a unique environment and I knew before clicking that viewers will hate it. It is perfectly fine for an RPG to start with modest levels with modest environments moving to different varied levels. You will also get nostalgia factor from overseas users from the Slumdog millionaire movie.

author: @AriyaGavisti
text:
Alright man, as much as I wanna appreciate your efforts there are so many things you are neglecting. One of them being your own audience. Now, I don't know how the final version would be but right now I just don't see much soul into it. Also using Unreal 5 could be a death sentence. It's one of the most unoptimized engine available. Another thing is it being an "AAA" title, that already comes with a lot of expectations. That give rise to a lot of worries people should be having. The price, performance, content. Not saying you don't have it figured out but the presentation certainly didn't give me anything to chew on. 

You can very well prove me wrong. But so far it looks soulless, uninspired, buzzword ripoff of a franchise that I personally hold dear to my heart, and it's just not me. Hopefully next time you show the game at least some of my concerns could be proven wrong. Again man, not hating on it but can't just jump into trusting an "AAA developer" after everything going on in the industry.

Cautiously optimistic though. Next presentation will be telling.

author: @GautamSingh-bk3cq
text:
The entire gameplay mechanic feels like a copy of Sekiro . From the lock-on system to the parry mechanics, everything screams ‚Äúuninspired imitation,‚Äù and to make matters worse, these core systems haven‚Äôt even been implemented properly. The combat lacks fluidity, and the timing feels off, making it more frustrating than engaging. On top of that, the narrative continuity is completely absurd‚Äîhow are we supposed to believe that an average Mumbaikar can suddenly pull off advanced Shinobi techniques? It completely breaks immersion and comes across as poorly thought out fanfiction rather than a grounded or coherent story.

Instead of attempting to create yet another half-baked ‚ÄúSoulsborne‚Äù clone or trying to build the next so-called ‚ÄúGTA killer‚Äù without the budget, talent pool, or years of R&D that studios like Rockstar pour into their projects, developers should focus on originality and cultural depth. Take Raji as a shining example‚Äîa beautifully crafted game by Indian developers that authentically integrates Indian mythology and storytelling into its gameplay and visual design. It‚Äôs unique, rooted in our culture, and most importantly, it respects the intelligence and expectations of its audience. Rather than chasing trends or mimicking global giants, maybe it‚Äôs time we start creating games that reflect our own narratives, legends, and creativity with sincerity and innovation.

author: @puspaltarafdar2465
text:
Amazing effort!!! Although this is a very early build and surely a lot more will be added in the development process, here are some suggestions from me:

1.This is a fantasy game, go more artistic with the Lighting. In any fantasy game like Sekiro, Elden ring, God of War, DA Inquisition etc. you will see that they are much more artistic with their lighting choices. That‚Äôs because realistic lighting in fantasy games may look a little out of place. A more stylized lighting can make the visuals more appealing.

2.Blood splatters too far from where the impact is happening then vanishes in thin air. If there is blood, the blood should stain the clothes and skin, as well as fall on the ground and splash on the walls. If blood stains the weapon, make the character wipe off the blood as blood is highly corrosive to metal. Little details go a long way. Take inspiration from Ghost of Tsushima‚Äôs bloody combat.

3.When the player is walking there is no visual cue. If it is a muddy ground, there should be footprints, if not footprints then at least make little splashes of water. If the ground is dry, there can be a little dust whenever the foot hits the ground. Different games do it in different ways. Some kind of visual sensation will surely make the movement of the player feel better.

4.The boss is yelling, but his mouth is visibly closed at all times, looks odd. You can either animate the face with the sound or play with the lighting and headgear to subtly hide the face during the battle. Sekiro does both with different bosses.

author: @ryokorp5393
text:
Good idea but here are some suggestions:
1.Gameplay straight up looks like sekiro shadows die twice. Its not a bad thing but innovate on the idea. 
2. Remove the shrine thing. Add temples/mandirs instead, see ? Some simple tweeks here and there would solve the problems but those tweask should be innovative or creative imo.
2. Dont make the combat souls like if that was your vision initially or is now after i have seen everyone sayin the enemies should be aggressive or something.yess the enemies should be aggressive but the gameplay shouldnt be relying on fast movements like sekiro but a mix of gameplay complexities and fast movement. By gameplay complexity i mean rpg elements that enhances your character in unique ways. Keep it balanced for a engaging yet challanging combat. Gameplay>>> graphics just dont try to make this a souls like pls 
3. Doesn't matter if the game is of 20 hours or 10 but dont make the things repetitive. Always keep adding new things as the game progresses and not the in the spoon feeding way but keep it just this much open so it allows a sense of discovery, kind of like botw tofk. Actually it would be very fun and interesting to have a botw tofk kinda game from india that doesnt go flashy with being a aaa game but just stays fun, engaging yet challenging. I hope you crack the code, you are doing great bro!!!‚ù§

author: @sanket.solanke
text:
Everything in the demo looked ugly together. I know it's alpha footage, but you can polish it 100 times and it'll still look ugly. I hope the style is drastically different in final product. More visually harmonic and less chaotic random.

Hire a director, or take help from someone. World building is a big part of any game. You have to do that with not just the story but visually too.

Imagine a game like god of war, but instead of being set in ancient Greece, it is set in slums of Mumbai with "bollywood" twist.

Every once in a while there is a game maker in India who try to make a "game set in India" and not a game. Don't fall into same trap.

Sure assets are good, may be mechanics are good to but you want to tell a story inspired of Ramayan, set in a slum, there is a guy with a sword dressed out of time, there is police in uniform and guns, a guy in safari with pipe, a giant south Indian with a mace, "bollywood" style and everything looks a mess. Is it similar to some places in India? Yes. But it looks like a place most people would not like to be in. 

Make something beautiful not realistic. Nobody is attracted by what they perceive as ugly.

author: @Future_Guy
text:
Disclaimer: I am exhausted by looking at the existing state of the Indian gaming industry and most of my opinions have been negative with respect to the approach most Indian developers take. So whatever I say below is coming from this existing lens. Positive and negative. (And I see there's 4K+ comments, maybe something will get repeated from those.) I am a developer myself so I am 100% into the know how. I am not a bystander commenting on something I know nothing about. Here goes -- 

Set Design - I've seen a couple of AAA games in development who've released their trailers/teasers and one thing common across them is the incredible set design. I absolutely LOVE how the environments end up looking. Photo-realism is not my first thought but many (including you) have managed to get that. Scanning is obviously an incredible technological marvel and with a lower entry bar I am glad that developers are utilizing it to it's full potential. I like your approach with the creation of the rig to scan clothes and everything else. Perfect Indian jugaad indeed. I will add one point here which is scanning the mannequins in a T-pose. 

Animations - It is indeed a lot of effort. I highly commend all the hours your team has put into this. MY problem however is that MoCap to Gameplay transition has to be a lot more seamless. There's a high level of detail that seems to be missing. The fights that happen is where it is apparent. The attacks don't connect naturally. There's a lot of force that is missing. It feels like dandiya. Also, the facial features were missing but this is only a problem since you've added faces! Most games create face masks or really twisted faces so that the connect with realism goes away. Objective here is to immerse the player with the fight. I look at the policeman with this wide eyes and I am immediately out of the zone. (This is also more of a industry wide issue. There is the "uncanny valley" effect. The player will never be able to pinpoint what exactly is off but they will always feel it.)

Gameplay - There is a rule that the first 2 minutes of the game should be exciting enough for the player to continue playing. You're yet to achieve that. FTUE is what matters. I've played over 200 games until now and I regularly play games after work (yes, sad I know). Valve does this very well. They have perfected the art of introducing gameplay through a very naturally occuring curve. For example, they will introduce the first enemy in an environment where it cannot reach the player thereby ensuring that the player is safe. Also provide them with a weapon that they can practice with how many times ever they want. Half Life Alyx did that with a gun and unlimited bullets. Half Life 2 did that with the saw blade. Portal does that the first time they introduce the turrets. It's fantastic and it ALWAYS works. Upon watching the gameplay here it just felt like what the hell is this guy? Why does he have a sword? Why is he attacking policemen? There is a disconnect right of the bat. For me at least. 

Enemies - You said that you're trying to create a bollywood style game. Can you please not? I really beg of you to not aim for that. Movies are not games. Games are not movies. There is an inherent difference in the larger than life sequences in movies that we prefer to watch but if that takes you out of the gameplay, then is it worth it? I really like the last enemy but the previous ones were very mediocre. And I absolutely hated the small clip of the hero running his hands on his hair. It was very tacky. UNLESS you are targetting a particular type of audience, this is not what the masses want. DMC (Devil May Cry) has such animations as well but they feel good because of the lineage they have created with their games. The first DMC wasn't made with that intention but now they have a lot of story and lore to support it. This hero here, is a nobody now. 

Story - This is a very common thing that almost all the big games that came out did. They ALWAYS target Mythology. Main reason being that you don't have to write a story. It already exists. I personally am not a fan of this trope. It is very low effort but there are outliers. Look at Raji and Asura. Both amazing games that utilize Indian mythology in a very unique manner. Here, I feel like you're going for a story where the hero can tap into the powers of Vishnu's Avatars? In the teaser he is tapping into Krishna it seems. The other games coming out are targetting Indian mythos or history. I am not a fan but hopefully you will do justice with it. 

Conclusion - I don't think I have seen a YouTuber get into Gaming before (in India) and I hope you are getting into this with the right mindset. You might be concentrating more on realistic set design now but it is a step that should be taken after making more gameplay. Please look at some dev diaries of Valve games or Ubisoft games or any other studio. Better gameplay ensures better player feel. The environments are visible for a few seconds. They are not the focus. I don't look at the foliage ALL the time in Sekiro or the amazing levels of Uncharted! I look at it once and it's gone the moment I am out of that area. I am not going to look at the way the rickshaw looks or the Tomato lorry looks for more than 10 seconds. But what am I doing 90% of the time? Controlling the character. I constantly look at the hero animating with respect to teh environment or enemies. 

I hope you get something useful out of this. I could talk so much more about this. I honestly love games and seeing you make this makes me feel so proud. I just want it to be done well. Good luck! :)

author: @akshatmudgal2130
text:
First of all this looks amazing, considering this is pre alpha and a souls like, here are a few suggestions you can consider:
1. Visually this is great, better than anything that has come from India, but you can work on audio, using amazing bgms, getting voice actors (or good AI voiceovers) for every enemy and some good ambient sounds.
2. The animations can be a smoother for every character.
3. The attacks look great but the damage it is doing is not translated somehow.
4. This is purely developers choice but if we can see some dismemberment for the enemies it will just elevate the experience.
5. And most importantly visually you have won half the battle, but please have a great story so that this can blow up like wukong did.

Thats just some suggestions but what this looks as pre alpha is mind blowing, kudos and All the best to you guys.
PS : launch it for PS and Xbox too

author: @Raxx_Bhai
text:
Not critizing, but seems like your team is small and the work is rushed (I mean 8 months... For 80 people... To make a high quality game, it's actually kinda impossible, and this game itself feels rushed). Seems like you have used sound effects that are... Chinese? Japanese? I mean at the start of the trailer, listen carefully. Also, the idea of using a temple-like structure at the middle of the street is... It kinda rings the bells from Black myth wukong, and not gonna lie, this game looks to be a recreated version of Black myth wukong. It would be appreciated if you were able to match the industry standard quality without rushing and having an actual big team of 150-200 people (it may sound a lot, but it's normal for AAA studios. While games like Black myth wukong and Detroit become human got 140-150 people, BOTW, Elden Ring, and many other AAA catagory games with high quality graphics had a team of around 300 people or even more than that. Gta 5 and RE8 had over a 1000 people).

Btw, really admire the idea of retelling the entire story of Ramayan via this game and it will be appreciated to continue with the project. Would be even proud if I somehow got to work for you.

Keep doing it even if it doesn't work out as you have planned, things click when you least expect them to.‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§

text:
Not sure if you will see this but it would be in your best intrest to set up a steam page already so that your game has its wishlists rolling in, it also helps create hype for the game which would help it upon it releases, Putting it up at steam should probably be your first priority as part of the marketing as its a great platform that many gamers use although it takes 30% of the cut the revenue you make from it would make it worth it , after all you can also have it on different platforms

Also some points i would like to add , make the game more challenging the fights that you showed us looked liked it was part of a tutorial, same as the boss another one is that the envirement should be a lot larger than what you have , my personal opinion is that you should atleast have 1 part where theres a forest with maybe a banyan tree with a monk etc (it would be cool thats all you dont need to take this seriously)

Hope this helps i love the effort and good luck ‚ù§.

author: @aakashsensharma7675
text:
Feels like a cheap sekiro copy. I want Indian game studios to thrive, but copying concepts blatantly won't work.
1. The posture bar is a straight copy from sekiro
2. The danger symbol on unblockables is exactly like sekiro too where a danger kanji is flashed before the attack.
3. The block and hit upon critical state is exact copy of sekiro.
4. Shrine with rest and travel system -- blatant copy

Nothing original has been presented in the showcase and I don't see a reason for the game to exist. 
Don't know why the dude presenting is so proud of what they've done.
I know it's an alpha but none of the movements are polished and seem out of place.

author: @SouL-ob5wx
text: This is sekiro...Down to the posture break animations, the little red dot that appears on the enemies when you posture break them to shrines, quickslots, the red glowing danger(sankat) sign on top of the character's head when the enemy does an unblockable attack. What is original about the combat and gameplay? My criticism might seem harsh but try to understand my key point. *Why would someone play this over the actual sekiro?* And if you do plan on adding your own original ideas into the game, why even reveal the existence of the game *without introducing any new key original ideas?*

author: @debanganchakraborty117
text:
Great work done by the team! But why does some of it feel like Sekiro? Though it's the alpha build, animations and combat mechanics can be much better. You have the time, please focus on improving the game mechanics and story more than just the graphics. Also judging from the graphics (with probably further enhancements in the future) it looks like this game would be heavy hardware demanding (maybe RTX 40 or 50 series GPUs at bare minimum). Please optimize the game so that a large number of players with mid range rigs can also get interested in buying and playing the game. 

Games like black myth wukong are kinda play once type of game because their only objective is to deliver an immersive story. UTA's development should also be more biased towards the story imo so that it becomes a successful launch.

Please consider this as a small piece of suggestion from a gamer's end. Rooting for UTA's success!!

author: @prajyotkumar9644
text:
There are some suggestions if you like.

1. Normal enemies are too calm, they should be a bit more aggressive to feel a certain tension.
2. Attack feels hollow, it needs to have a bit more animation. You can shake the camera a bit more dramatically for that especially the attacks after parrying.
3. Enviroment is too small. I think some bigger games had this issue in past and it almost killed that game so Make your environment big so people don't feel like they are constrained.
4. Same with boss, the aftereffects of his attack were good but he heavily lacked variety and also his attacks when it hit the character were lackluster. Also every enemy of yours felt slow in movement. 

Since its alpha build, I hope you take these into consideration. Good luck

author: @vaishnavinegi4461
text:
First of all, I am very happy that someone who has the means also has the courage to build a game that is based on India. So kudos for that. 
But if you want some constructive criticism, here it is. 

That small mandir has kachra in front of it. I know we have a waste problem in India, but I have never seen a temple or smaller shrines surrounded by waste. Maybe it is just me, but that was my immediate response. 
As you say, Bollywood style, it really feels like that because one policeman has a laathi(maybe a constable?) while the other has a gun, but even after that, he is not shooting. But later he shoots, and our hero is miraculously safe since Goli hit the talwar, no goli ka charra, nothing.
Also, in Kshudita Asura, his foot is in a puddle, but the water doesn't have any effect most of the time, except for one time. When the hero hits him, there are no after effects like Kapde katna and all.
I know some of these are very minute things. But, there are so many things I can point out that will ruin the experience of gaming while playing, because these things subconsciously affect the whole experience.

Also, since you guys used Hindi fonts sometimes, like SANKAT, if someone doesn't know Hindi, how will they know what is written? Is there any option for language? 

I hope you read this and think about it. I really want this game to be successful. All the very best.

text:
I understand the game is still in its alpha phase, and I just wanted to share an observation that could help improve immersion. When a wooden stick collides with a steel sword, the sound effect currently resembles the sound of two steel swords striking each other. This doesn‚Äôt reflect the expected material interaction and slightly breaks the immersion during gameplay.

As an experienced game tester with 4.8 years of experience including testing AAA titles, mobile games, and PC/cloud-based games I‚Äôve seen how much of a difference accurate sound design can make to the overall feel of a game. 

I just wanted to highlight this as part of helpful feedback. Overall, the trailer looks really cool wishing the team all the best with the development! Also, please let me know if there‚Äôs any opportunity to contribute further by testing this game I‚Äôd love to be involved in any way I can.

author: @spelgrafiken
text:
Please focus on the fun.
Games are made to be played, not just admired for graphics, scale, or production value. If your game is actually fun, players won‚Äôt care whether it‚Äôs AAA, indie, 2D, or 3D ‚Äî we‚Äôll support it, talk about it, and build a community around it. That‚Äôs how true legacies are made.

Too many devs fall into the trap of comparing their project with AAA games. But even AAA titles worth 1000 crores fail when they lack soul. That‚Äôs why fun should be the foundation ‚Äî not comparison.

Honestly, most gamers don‚Äôt care about how big your team is, what engine you‚Äôre using, or if it‚Äôs 'India‚Äôs first this or that.' We care if it‚Äôs engaging, satisfying, and worth our time. That‚Äôs what matters.

I‚Äôm saying this as someone who wants to see great games come out of India. Not just good-looking ones ‚Äî great ones. If the vision gets lost in comparisons and marketing hype, the game might look polished, but won‚Äôt leave a mark.

So please ‚Äî stay true to your vision. Don‚Äôt build a game to prove a point. Build it to make people feel something. If you do that, success will follow, no matter the genre, platform, or budget.

REMEBER = Gamers do not remember budget, THEY REMEMBER MOMENTS!!!

Edit - my previous comment tone was harsh and too blunt, that's why I used AI

author: @kishanv9879
text:
Wow that's a great initiative. Congratulations üéâ
I've been playing game for 20yrs i have some suggestions and improvements.

I love the movement of the protagonist. He is very agile and his leg movement and placements are really good. Thats will make a fluid character movement. 

Suggestions:
1. You can change the color grading of the game. its feeling dull.
2. The space is too small for the protagonist to fight since he is using a sword. He needs a wider pathe to dodge and counter (Refer dmc, sekiro, souls games, prince of persia warrior within)
3. Stick to 1 style of play since it seems a linear gameplay rather open world. Since the gameplay showcase the stealth takedown then sword to sword and sword to gun play. It will complicate development plans and also for the users gameplay. Need a core gameplay mechanics ( eg. Splinter cell, soldier elite 2, mad payne)
4. Can reduce the high quality assets that represent the realtime objects. It will create compatibility issues in many pc due to optimisation. Changing the art design will help a lot. (E.g dishonored, the lost crown, ryse son of rome)

Thats it!

Love to see the game after completion üéâ

author: @codewithmePuneet
text:
Imho dont focus on story that much, rather make a fun to play game with great movements and weapon selection. Go for multiple boss figts. A souls like game would can become popular very easily as the story is not the main selling point of the game, its the difficulty. Also you'll be able to save money on story and script writing and can very easily take a iterative development approach where you make one boss and immediately give it your testers. No linking stories between levels. 

World looks absolutely gorgeous right now, basically the other thing that is in a typical souls game. So you'll be able to pretty much play into your exisiting game. Remove any cops or npcs that look out of place, either everyone has a gun or no one. Bringing a sword to a gun fight wont fly with critics (also using indian cops can get your game banned pretty quick).

I would love that you have a more dark and gritty world surroundings and use indian mythological demons as bosses. That would be so damn cool. 

Nontheless game looks great for alpha, gorgeous world

author: @L0neWolf_
text:
Hey Varun,
I have been a gamer from past 10+ years. I've played all sorts of games. What you're doing is going to change future if done right otherwise the future is going to remain the same like how it is from past couple of years (Companies focusing on revenue generating games and mostly on mobile). I still see a lot of gaps in this teaser, some of it is cringe and not quality. I may get hatred for this but people who are going to buy this game are definitely going to compare this game to other AAA titles and if you're claiming this as a AAA then this should be delivered as a AAA title. The script, narration, gameplay, BGM everything. I just want to help you here because there are a lot of people who want to become a part of this industry but it's very difficult in India. I would request you to take time, roll out an alpha, get some feedback and refine. This is not going to be easy for sure but I want to wish you all the best for this!

Edit:
I don't know whether you've seen SIFU. It's a fairly small game but the gameplay, mechanism, combat, story is top-notch. Please have a look

author: @grapetape5854
text:
If you read this Varun, i hope that this game kickstarts the AAA games for india,

But some things you can do to improve the game as well which many people might find a bit odd. With all due respect, what you have done is mindblowing and take courage to even execute.

What the game needs a bit more is dynamic and object colisions.

Small details like footprints and wet ground affecting the surrounding.

Facial expressions is something that if done perfectly, will show results and build more depth.

Even while in combact, the protagonist should react differently for every attack type and not just parry without any blow backwards.

Fluidity in combat is also a crucial thing in games, understanding that this is the first build, you will improve things and well all know how much of a passion you can put in these projects.

These things can be ironed out by just in a few months of more work but this will be the last stretch for the development 

Playtest game and try to find actual gamers to play this game and give you their honest review before launch as a Playtest because thats where small things miss and leave a bad taste
And a game of this Calibre, you have literally a lot to manage and little to no leg room for errors

But one thing is for sure, You can take your time to make things so perfect that no one will be able to find mistakes in this game.


And i know you know this as well because you made the game. 

People will compare this to other AAA games and its an Uphill battle for you to make 'OUR' game Worthy for world wide recognition.

You have My wishes and i would buy this game.

author: @suryanshpatel604
text:
Congratulations! And I am really proud that we have real problem solvers in the Indian gaming scene! Having a small team of 40 young artists and building something of this scale must have taken a lot of effort!

However, I have some feedback and early criticism based on the small fraction of gameplay shown of the game in alpha stage.

1. Artistic distinction: Unreal engine was the right choice because of its pricing structure, but it has a generic look to it. It was evident in the gameplay without the unreal engine splash screen. Having a small team is tough but I feel like it has a big advantage of having the opportunity to have artistic distinction. The engine is great at achieving cheap realism, but there is opportunity to do more with less. Unreal has a huge library of scans and doing your own to match those feels like going forward resources and time can be better utilised.
Another thing is eye candy. There is a huge opportunity to celebrate Indian colours, the game currently seems to lack exactly that. The Avatar transformation at the end gave me goosebumps, majorly being a great scene but also because thats the first time it felt like the game had Indian colours! Real life is boring, games have the opportunity to exaggerate life and be fun!

2. Visual fidelity: It was brave incorporating 3D scans of real places in the game and they are awesome! However, it feels like there is a mismatch between the high fidelity massive environment and low fidelity NPCs (protagonist though, really really great!). Also, many textures are a bit too high resolution like the side walls in contrast to low texture mud and grass right next to it making it visually jarring. Maybe in the beta stage of the game you can even them out. Also scanning every material makes it boring, for example, the metal sheets and the plastic covers and the walls of huts and sheds all have the same texture! Since Unreal engine has great materials readily available, maybe mixing and matching your scans with sprinkle of different textures would be amazing!

3. Scattered focus: I suggest that it would be great if shortcuts are taken in the upcoming developments in the environment, having intentional focus only on monuments and objects the director feels important for the plot. Everything being equally crisp, bright and in focus gives the initial awe feeling but eventually makes it hard to focus on the things that actually matter.
For example, the dense buildings in the distance may be reduced with cheap haze/fog giving it a sense of volume but not taking away the focus of the player. The shrine may have visual cues, or maybe distinctly have bright texture while the background may have muddy textures, so that the shrine pops.

4. Stage building (?): I assume the game has a linear plot and it is not an open world game but it doesn't have to have extremely linear paths. From the players perspective holding W or thumb stick up all the time can be very boring and tiring! Random turns, corners and some dead ends, not having enemies in direct sight all the way to the end of the path would be amazing and may feel more interactive!

5. Character: In the current state, the characters feel a little less alive. Rigging faces of every character is hard, but I hope at least eyes of major enemies during special attacks could move to show some emotions and not be robotic. At least protagonist should definitely have some expressions especially because there are closeups. And definitely distinct voice for the protagonist, during actions, attacks and other engagements it would be nice to have the character making noises. 

I think the efforts need to be directed to game direction than making the game look extremely good like a tech demo, but then what do I know about game production hahah! But often there are ground breaking games built solo or by a team of 2-4 people. Concepts and direction go a long way!

What I love about the game is how its paving way for itself. I really really want it to succeed, its like my own dream is coming to life! All the best wishes and looking forward to a finished game! I will definitely buy the game!

BTW overall it was really good and please consider the above flaws in gameplay, take time guys, best wishes with you ‚ù§‚ù§

author: @stacksmasherninja7266
text:
oh no it is unreal engine -- noooo

okay this is impressive for a team of 40 in 8 months. the assets and all are also very good. 

but please, please, please, please, please add some unique movements or good, very fun game mechanics. people play games because they're fun or memorable stories, not because they look good

i don't care how good it looks -- all of the visuals are completely pointless if the game environment isn't good. i need to FEEL the chaos that is india

it's nice that you got a very good scans, but you could've easily done the visuals through clever shaders. your high quality scans and assets just mean the game is heavy on hdd storage. i know its very cool to scan things -- trust me i've done that as a phd student in computer graphics. but it's also pointless since majority of the audience do not care. i would've been far more excited if you took existing free assets and cleverly perturbed them to fit the indian aesthetic. there's actual, real, well funded research that goes on in this area. try consulting profs in india who are working in this.

please don't just become a hogwarts legacy -- all show and mediocre story with grindy after-story experience

author: @hrishabhdivya
text:
A game is not just about its gameplay but also the storyline and the core premise it embodies. It is crucial to recognize that this game will represent India on a global stage, much like how "Wu Kong" showcased China's cultural narratives to international audiences.
Therefore, I urge you to ensure that there is no compromise on quality. At the same time, it is essential to retain the essence of Indian culture within the game, as this will make it unique and distinguishable from Western games. This distinctiveness will not only attract global players but also position India prominently on the map of game development.
Please take the time required to craft a masterpiece worthy of its purpose.

author: @014revenger
text: This is just meh. Even meh is an overstatement tbh. Extremely graphics are for a niche audience. All I see here is an Unreal Engine tech demo and really bad one at that. Anyone with bare minumum knowledge of unreal engine can cook up a scene like this in less than a week. Visuals amount to nothing without a good story, mechanics, combat and sound design among other things. People should stop unnecessarily hyping this game by comparing it with games that took years to master. Indian games will always fail if you set the bar this high. Like someone else pointed out, I want to see Indian studios making Indie games like, inside, hades, dead cells, hollow knight or even blasphemous. These are award wining indie games that don't have a AAA budget.

author: @numina_pen
text: Amazing to see an indian game development team finally try to make a AA or AAA quality game,  but i am really worried about some things after seeing the trailer, the base game mechanics of the game do not feel strong to me, there is a lack of feedback in the parries and hits, the npcs feel a bit stiff, the overall game feel can be improved quite a bit, the animations look a little bit stiff at times as well and even the boss (while only one boss was showcased, and i dont want to judge the whole game because of this ) seemed to have a not so interesting attack pattern. SInce this is an alpha build , i really hope they can get people to test the game, fix some of the issues that i mentioned above and improve based on feedback. And while fall 2026 seems like a bit of an early release date considering how many things can be improved, i am really hoping they are able to deliver a product that is polished and well made. Kudos to the development team again, I hope you become the pride of Indian game development and put India on par with other industry giants in the space. I am rooting for you!!

author: @sola7078
text:
I don't know where this notion that "other studios don't use photogrammetry" is coming from. Maybe that's only referring to Indian devs? In the "west" it's been a pretty core part of the asset pipeline for most AAA studios going back the last 10 years. Pre-production often involves a team of art and tech people going to suitable locations to gather scan data for an asset library. 

Anyway, nice to see something more ambitious coming from India. Wishing you all the luck.

text: This is the problem with modern gaming. Just see for yourself how much time was used to showcase realistic graphics, and the effort that went behind it rather than what makes gameplay fun. Hey Varun, I really appreciate the team behind making this game possible, but I want to ask you about the core concept behind making this game? To me, it just felt like Indianising a gameplay format, and I really don't understand why the hero is ki*ling the police and native people or a "Gunda". author: @ExpTest-im1id
text:
Combat looks fine.
Need more ambiance sounds to truly believe we are in that environment.
You need reward and weapons upgrade system. This drives engagement. ex. Clearing an area or killing a boss unlocks an artifact to upgrade the weapon.
Unrealistic parts: the setting is Indian. A police guy, can call for backup and thousands of enemies would spawn and then you go into hiding till cooldown. A lot of games have this system.
Story or journey of that guy - what's driving him to fight these guys? - Murder of father, puppy or kidnapping of daughter?
Side missions - to help other characters, share stories and learn about the surroundings, I love exploration.

You could look into those aspects.

author: @arrshK
text:
I hope you are open to critiques coz oh boy i have a lot to talk about this!

You guys are aiming to set a benchmark which is already quite high with souls games and *good* AAA games (only comparing in your competing market) so it will be a really tough job to make this game ab ove par and i can see that you people gave done an mind-blowing job :D 

Now lets talk about the game itself...

Since the footage we saw was the alpha build i wont be too harsh and not point the obvious.

Assets: you said it yourself nothing for me to talk about. 10/10

Gameplay: The first thing i notices is that you took inspiration from both Black Myth Wukong and Sekiro (which you stated later) and i am really excited about it because i SALIVATE on sekiro combat! Yes some polishing can be done but lets ot talk about it. And i am assuming you got the Shrine and the over the top dodging animation from BMW and i really like it but the only problem that i can see with what we've seen till now is that the combat isnt as interesting... Sure the system itself is from sekiro but the combat moveset seems sluggish and limited. Thats all i can say about the GamePlay and combat based on what we've seen.

NPCs: They look uncanny and very off, i would suggest looking into Yakuza Games and how they do it.

Story: Since youve kept the story a secret i cannt judge the footage from it but all i can say is, citing Hollow Knight's Gametester "everything needs to fit in the world, nothing should feel out of place." and i stand by this golden rule and this raises lots of questions in my mind. Why is the mc dressed like that? Why is the starting area is mumbai slums? why does the main character have an anciant sword while everyone else is using things similar to danda? Why are we fighting priests in the SLUMS? Why are we killing normal residents? why are the police involved? I would love the story to answer these questions and raise more!

Music: Pretty good! cant say further due to limited footage

Aaand thats it! Thats all what i have to say about the current state of the game that has been released to public. I am really looking forward to what comes next and making our nation stand out (in a +ve way ) in the video game feild :D

- Arrsh

feedback:
1. NPCs looked really smooth and low quality compared to protagonist (I hope NPCs will match quality of protagonists and overall becomes much better)

If all those points are checked and more dynamics environment this game will not just match international AAA standards but surpass in most cases.

Hey Varun, This Looks AMAZING!!! ‚ú®‚ú®
I as a kid loved gaming, even though I didn‚Äôt have computer at home. I used to play Vice City Stories on my PS Portable. I have played a lot of games since my childhood. author: @gameswithfrank
text:
nice demo! felt some lost legacy vibes.. but man.. I was expecting something like Balatro or Undertale or Venba.. then i realized that high quality game for most Indians means high graphics.. anyway who cares how a game succeeds.. amirite

here are my thoughts (as a gamedev) :
1. nice use of photogrammetry.. I wonder how much of it was done through that.. because I see a lot of such meshes 6:44 (the windows on the right end have leaking textures) but yeah only Unreal can handle such meshes through nanite.. The barricade is def not photogrammetry (and by that I mean 3D scanned meshes, if anyone who is curious, please look up tools like Reality Capture.. basically it takes a shit ton of photos and gives out a 3d model..)
2. combat looks nice but at 8:04 there's no impact on the player's model.. that would feel a bit more realistic.. and a minor fix- the boss is hovering on the ground at 8:20 .. the collider might be off.. also blood fx look kinda outdated..
3. character transformation vfx were great at the end.. 
also careful with accidentally showing brands 7:42 unless Hero is like a partner.. idk..
but will it be a good game? depends on what will be added.. because all I see nowadays are Indian versions of Ghost of Tsushima, Black Myth Wukong and GTA but there's not much difference from their 'inspiration'.. I wish lesser demos are made and more games are released.. because the whole character transformation scene could've taken a lot of effort which doesn't really translate into the whole gameplay? maybe one cutscene but yeah, fall 2026 is too early for a game like this imho.. so that's implying somewhere around 16 months of development.. 2 times the effort that was put into the game in it's current state.. do you think the gameplay would be more than an hour?
just some questions to know answers to for the success of the game...

author: @sineinunison
text:
my opinions:
-this has a lot of potential.
-the gui doesn't really match with the game, please add some changes (other wise it just looks like a sticker on a real video).
-most important: make the game look good and natural, not "realistic".
-do work on the particle effects.
-do work the facial expressions of both the protagonist and the npc.
-work on post effects, people love games that feel like games.
-make the camera more stable
-you guys have a lot of potential, please properly release it üò≠
-work on noticeable details, because most people won't keep checking if everything is "real" or not.
-add gore, or light gore like Ghost of Tsushima. because just having blood fly out with no expression of pain or agony from the enemies makes it feel like more of a "made with unity" game ‚ò† .
-yes, you do need to work on the combat system.
-it would for us low end gamers if you use pre-rendered shadows at some areas. 
-i love you guys, i'm proud.

author: @arnabkar8792
text:
My two cents on this as someone who plays a lot of videogames, the setting feels a lil jarring. Don't know the story yet, but I have so many questions like why is the character "killling", not beating up, killing people. Why are cops being killed, what's the basis of the powers and everything invloved.
I know it's pre-alpha, these things don't matter yet, the game looks absolutely amazing for pre-alpha actually, nearing completion by those standards. But make sure to have a decent amount of depth in the game, maybe normalise these supernatural powers so that even the thugs have powers of some kind, it also keeps a progression system in sight and keeps it sensible.
TLDR: Make it make sense, focus on the depth factors like worldbuilding, story, gameplay and how they influence and intertwine with each other.

author: @arfathahmed3433
text: Huge respect! Ambitions are high. But here's my take - there are many ambitious projects out there - many of which showcase a small scale demo with high quality graphics with hopes of releasing a full project that delivers. But reality is that graphics is never the only thing that gamers seek. What sticks with gamers is art style, gameplay, story and anything with a lasting impression. Gamers know that indie can excel well beyond AAAs if done right. You don't need realistic - Unreal Engine - esq graphics for that. I would love for India to succeed, I strongly believe we have the talent for it. I also strongly believe that effort and money should be spent well. You are in the best position to determine that. My opinion would be to draw in more inspiration from successful indie projects. Also - do not claim "High quality", let the product speak for itself.

author: @Thanas.R
text:
Hi Varun,

First of all, hats off to you and your team for the incredible effort you've put into the game. I can only imagine how much time, dedication, and resources it takes to bring a world like this to life. Visually, the game looks absolutely stunning, and the world you've created feels rich and immersive ‚Äî that‚Äôs no small feat.

That said, I wanted to share some honest feedback. While the visuals and setting are impressive, the gameplay footage didn‚Äôt quite resonate with me. It felt a bit disconnected and somewhat lacking in coherence ‚Äî for instance, seeing a sword-wielding character go up against a police officer with a gun came across as a bit random and mismatched. This contrast made the gameplay feel a bit silly and hard to take seriously, which might affect how players connect with the overall experience.

I truly believe that gameplay is the heart of any great game, and if the mechanics and tone don‚Äôt align with the world you've built, it can be difficult for players to fully immerse themselves. Also the Character models didn't seem right. I hope you and your team take the time to refine and polish the core experience, because there‚Äôs so much potential here. With the right tweaks, this could become something truly special.

Wishing you and your team all the very best in the rest of the development process ‚Äî I‚Äôm rooting for you and looking forward to seeing how the game evolves!

[ also it would be nice to get a heart from you to know it read this post ]

author: @Techtipsdtyagi
text:
First of all, congratulations to you and the entire team for your hard work‚Äîthis is a great achievement. As a senior AAA game artist, I truly appreciate the effort put into the project. That said, I believe there are areas where things could be improved with a bit more finesse.

Many of the scenes and levels currently feel a bit flat, and a lot of the props seem to have excessive roughness. While the depiction of Mumbai's slum areas is impressive, the placement of grass and small plants‚Äîlikely from Megascans‚Äîfeels random in some spots. In reality, due to space constraints in such areas, vegetation is often much more sparse or selectively present, which isn‚Äôt reflected well in the level design.

With Unreal‚Äôs latest features like displacement and Nanite, there‚Äôs a lot of potential to enhance both performance and visual quality. As you have a great team that has worked on amazing titles and movie projects, I‚Äôd love to see their skills utilized in even smarter and more creative ways moving forward.

This isn‚Äôt meant as a criticism but rather a suggestion from someone who‚Äôs passionate about quality and authenticity in game environments. Looking forward to future updates and improvements. All the best to the team.
