author: @d_roy_
text:
Idk if you'll see the comment, but this comment includes 2 pieces of feedback that I believe will help make things better!

This looks pretty good for Alpha! I am a gamer myself, who also happens to be into CS, AI and Computer Vision, but I also love gaming, so I have played a lot of games so far. One thing I focus a lot on is the feel of the gameplay, the animations and the plot. 

There is ONE feedback I'd like to give in that regard:
07:06 Here, when I see the buildup to the finisher animation, I predict a piercing strike coming. Like when the character charges the blade behind, it seems as if he's readying a piercing move, shoving the blade up the enemy's stomach/chest, something like that. But it AWKWARDLY cuts in this cross slash animation, which really doesn't connect well with the ramp up. Assuming this is the way you intended things to be, it's not a good finisher animation. 

Apart from this, I don't see any glaring issues for an Alpha build. I'd honestly love to give more feedback as well, because as I said again, I love gaming as a hobby on the side, a passionate hobby you could say. Some of the movement animations look janky, but that's to expected from an alpha build. Hope to see more refinement in the finer details of the game!

EDIT: Another feedback:
08:27 Here, it seems like this is a perfect dodge? It's a cool animation, but adding a bit more of post processing effects and visual FX might help actually accentuate the impact of the perfect dodge. The SFX for it is good, but the visuals would need some touch up. Just giving my 2 cents for these 2 things I noticed, so the final version can be touched up accordingly!

author: @PenguinjitsuX
text:
This is awesome. However, need to add some criticism. While the scans and backgrounds are amazing, and you take a lot of pride in it and spend a lot of time talking about it, photorealistic graphics don't make a game. A game needs to be fun first and foremost. And currently, the gameplay shown just looked like a worse version of Sekiro and other similar games. I wish you showed off what makes your game actually unqiue - the Avatar (religious) aspect with the transformation. You should have actually showed that part so we can see what makes your game unique. What you showed off, unfortunately, is just a worse version of existing game mechanics and doesn't look high quality at all.

I know the game isn't finished, but especially because it is not done, it is more important to showcase why your game is special. People know things can be improved, but people only buy new games if they offer something different than the existing ones.

Thank you for taking the risk and bringing this. I'm definitely buying this game once its out.

author: @UsamaThakurr
text:
My Brutally Honest review:

First off good effort we can see the efforts but as you said you hired "skilled" People the results say they were NOT skilled. This looks like very bad version of any Souls game. I am not going to praise this I am sorry but this ain't it and you are NOT going to set any standards with this the Combat was VERY basic and NOT fun at all for a fun combat example please look at recent titles like "Khazan The First Berserker" And Monster Hunter Wilds. 

I know these are very high budget titles and a YouTuber can't afford something like this but I would suggest you create very fun gameplay oriented game because if we are weak at graphics and character building, story building and many others things that we indians lacks in we can excel in one thing inside gaming industry by creating actual fun games. 

What's a fun game? It's very subjective but the genre you chose the fun is defined by boss fights combats and of course we haven't seen the magic part of this game yet but by animations of character movements I can say it is not going to be good. 

I suggest you look at old school Nintendo games, Java phone games and many famous titles draw a architecture of it hire a Psychologist tell him to find you a sweet spot display a cinematic trailer and then decide on development. 

The D riding in the comments is crazy either you guys don't understand what a good game looks like or you are just d riding like you all do in all comments. Please be honest to our community don't say nice things give them constructive criticism no one is perfect everybody learns everyday and we should give then honest feedback so create the best. 

That's all best of luck on whatever you decide‚ù§

author: @alaapdhall8541
text:
The scenary is all good and environment can look good to obut honestly that doesn't matter. 

What matters is gameplay, immersiveness, world interaction. 

In your gameplay, wounds aren't visible, Avatar clothes hair don't move, blood splash is random, the fighting experience in itself isn't that great.
Story Line has to be 10/10 for your game to work, I won't comment on that since that's unknown. 
Your game word doesn't look interactive, it just looks realistic and I don't think that's enough. (Unless ofcourse this isn't an open world in which case your story will be the most important thing with gameplay)

You cannot just get away with good looking world in a game, it has to have a immersive gameplay and not static with 10/10 story that actually excites you to play more. 
If the story is just about Hinduism and you wish to ride a wave of "Hindu ya religion p video bana lo and paisa hi paisa" then you'll have a lot of Downloads but not many returning players.

author: @gjndragwla
text: As a 18 yo who has worked in 3d and currently jobless. I should say you did a great job. however i think you missed the oppurtinity of using the particle system. it should work great with the magical theme. and second photoscans are good for background assets, they can generate great geometry but when it comes to textures is sucks. it bakes things like ao in them which makes it look like they dont belong in the environment. A much better solution would have been to use the 3d scans as a refrence point and build new geometry on top of it and make custom pbr materials. cuz your 3d scans dont change lighting, reflections based on lighting and stuff. they look off. they look blurry as compared to the game also really bad at closeups. last but not least everything feels clunky like using assets and systems from fab. its not wrong but they need polishing. mainly the movement system. the environment dosent seem to react to the player much. its like a completely different set piece like footprints and stuff. the characters scale fells off as one cop is smaller than the mc. I really appreciate the work you put into this but it needs polishing and the decisign to use photoscan directly a bad idea. and as for 100% in engine screenshot well they are not cuz the lighting dosent effect the assets they are not pbr they are just base color textures slapped on them. they will look smae even withouting any shadows and lighting change. As for global benchmark well not really. this game really needs polish. and a tone to work with

These are just constructive criticism for the game, and i really want that this goes international like black myth, i wish you all the best, please take the criticisms positively. Really appreciate the hardwork!!

author: @siddharthshahi9577
text:
I‚Äôve been following your journey for a while now ‚Äî quietly, but with growing admiration. And today I just want to say, thank you.

‚ÄúUnleash The Avatar‚Äù isn‚Äôt just a game. It‚Äôs a statement. A bold one. And a necessary one.

What you and the team are doing ‚Äî building a AAA-quality game rooted in Indian culture, mythology, and design ‚Äî is brave, beautiful, and deeply important. Not because it proves anything to the world, but because it reminds us of what we‚Äôre capable of.

Far too many of us, growing up in India, quietly absorb a belief that we are somehow meant to play supporting roles on the global stage. That we‚Äôre better suited to follow than to lead, better at imitation than imagination. It‚Äôs not always said out loud ‚Äî but it‚Äôs there. In the caution, the doubt, the deference.

And over time, it dims our confidence. It shapes how we see ourselves. It makes us timid in our dreams and hesitant in our ambitions. And often, unintentionally, we pass that on ‚Äî pulling each other back under the guise of being ‚Äúpractical.‚Äù

That‚Äôs why what you‚Äôre building here matters so much.

UTA isn‚Äôt just a game ‚Äî it‚Äôs a vision of what happens when we stop asking for permission. It‚Äôs a powerful, 3D expression of Indian creativity, identity, and excellence ‚Äî built for us, by us, and proud of it. Not as a reaction to the world, but as a reflection of the best of who we are ‚Äî and could be.

Thank you for showing us that we don‚Äôt need to be the alternative ‚Äî we can be the aspiration.

Much love and strength to the whole team.
A long-time supporter and believer‚ù£

author: @dibyajyoti_ghosal
text:
The background is decent! But the NPCs need a lot of work I feel! Characters need facial expression, Npc animations need an overhaul! Dynamic displacement mapping, maybe even using decals can also add into the realism! For puddles, if you add screen space effects like splashing when moving over them can also greatly improve the experience. Finally, render resolution seemed a bit low (looking at the artifacts near the hair), along with lower quality textures! 
But having said all this, even though it is not exactly AAA title according to global standards today, but it's quite close to it, and some adjustments can really push this game to that level where your vision of creating a world class game where people won't be able to tell where it is from (excluding the story), can really come to life!
From a former amateur cry-engine game dev and a gamer with 17+ years of experience playing games :p
Wish you all the very best! Hopefully this reaches the AAA quality and you achieve what you've been dreaming!

author: @shuvojit8403
text:
Hi Varun, Love your demo. I am a fan of video games since childhood and being a game designer in making I have my 2 cents. Please take it as constructive criticism - 

- Background looks good, but rest of the element of the game feels a bit undercooked. 
- A Good game requires a satisfying core game loop and in-depth game mechanics. You complement those game mechanics with beautiful graphics. Not other way around. So, in a production pipeline of 8 months, graphics should not be a priority instead game design is first thing you need to get right. Get an experienced Game designer.
- Background music is awesome.
- I would recommend get a Narrative designer on the team. They will help you blend your story to the game. 
- Also Get a combat designer, to make the combat satisfying.
- Need more work on gamefeel.

Overall, feels more of a tech demo than a game.  Good wishes, please keep up the good work, eventually you will get there.

author: @DS00099
text:
I truly wish for your success in this journey but I believe a bit of criticism is necessary here. People from other countries often glorify only good parts from their cities and because we see those parts, We believe that‚Äôs the whole reality But the truth is, They have problems too, Just like we do.

The difference is, While they focus on showcasing the good, We tend to focus only on the bad. We believe we‚Äôre being truthful by showing the harsh realities and yes, that is part of the truth but then people start to think that‚Äôs the whole truth about us. It gives an incomplete and often unfair picture.

Also, you‚Äôll never see trash being thrown near small temples in those places or temples being built next to open drains. That‚Äôs something you guys need to change because it's far from reality.

Wishing you all the best.

author: @arunan8377
text:
This is a fantastic effort from India in gaming space.  But for someone who enjoyed gaming thanks to Roadrash and GTA - I have few pointers which you can work upon, because you are still in building phase and can make the product changes. If you are looking for a rational QA, I can help.

1. Characters can get little more facial emotions - it looks very stagnant.
2. When the characters are running through the muddy patch - it looks very flat; there is no splashes of puddle when the characters are running over it or when falling on the ground. Some amount of realism is appreciated.
3.  The main character looks the same even though he gets hit - show the scars/hit on the main char too - Later you can give some kind of addon that will fix his injuries.
4. Guns vs Traditional Swords - Guns would win any day/ But if you are going to showcase bullet deflection from sword you can show it holistically. That as a viewer or as a gamer can experience.

author: @evilhuntgaming835
text:
Game looks good, But here are some suggestions: 

1. While running the motion of character looks stiff. (looks like upper body especially the hand holding weapon is still and only legs and left arm are moving, the animation can be improved, 

2. The parry mechanism needs improvement, at 8:03 when our character blocks mace, it does not looks accurate(logically considering size of boss and his weapon vs our character in its normal form, once our character turns into an avatar, then some more enhanced mechanisn can be used there) 
for 1 & 2 you can take inspiration from Ghost of Tushima

3. The interaction with shrine feels very fast, its like just a press of button and nothing much happens on screen which does not provide the sense of achievement for completing a part or mission. The interaction can be improved at shrine. (I know you took some reference from Black Myth Wukong and balancing it from Indian religion Pov without hurting any section of society will be challenging)


other  suggestions: 

1. Performance optimization for low end devices (many of my frnds still use their 4-5 yrs old laptop with specs like  - i5 8 or 9 gen, 8 gb ram, Nvidia 920MX, 930MX or 1050. And even with high end machines I have seen people avoiding to push their machines to max as the laptop generated too much heat and GPU/ GPU temps are above 90 and and fans make too much noise. So despite the hardware is able to run game on high/ ultra setting people play on low/ medium setting on laptop ( key reason is they can't afford to change/ upgrade machines every 2-3 years, and they want to last it as long as possible)

2. Keeping the names of characters/ items in game a bit simpler but keeping the Indian touch and easy to pronounce especially for audience outside India as to make this project financially successful as well, a major contribution might come from other high income countries as disposable income and pc penetration in India is very low.

All the best for your journey, India definitely needed something like this

A feedback from a indie gamedev-  Please don't make a far cry or assasin creed with indian theme. A good aaa game doesn't just mean high quality graphics, it should have it's own feel,  story, and unique immersive gameplay.  
No hate but why does indian story always needs to be related to patriotism or ramayan or any other mythologies. We are capable enough to create our own story. Even if you create your own sci fi or any prehistoric game, the game will still be called an indian game. What you're doing is just using some photorealistic indian theme assets with gameplay of already existing foreign games. 
I know you have less manforce than an actual aaa studio, but that shouldn't be an excuse to make a low quality game. For example vice city is such a old with low graphics, but still provide better feel than many aaa games which are currently available. Hoping best for your game best of luck üëç.

author: @AmanBansil
text: (Writing from the US) This looks so cool. No pressure but if you can prove the market, indian gaming companies may start cropping up or you may have big american companies start getting interested in these markets. A suggestion for your team: Make the GAMEPLAY FUN. Look at titles like Ghost Of Tsushima. Make sure that the player is NOT dealing with bad combat mechanics. I say this because you're a videographer type and you're going to focus a lot of the visual, which is apparent by the fact that you spoke about visuals extensively. THAT SAME LEVEL OF RIGOR NEEDS TO BE IN THE GAMEPLAY MECHANICS. I'll try to share some thoughts - but generally, have your engineers also focus on the gameplay to feel enjoyable - it should take the kind of work it took to fix the visuals. Gotta go beyond the Unreal default or find libraries that make things feel much more real. ------- At 6:02, we can tell how well the cinematography is. We can tell that you love that stuff and it is showing. At 6:30 the character easily approaches a standing enemy with full running speed - ask yourself if that would be possible in real life. the NPC should punish you for being too bold and assuming the game is stupid enough to let you run up to the NPC and choke it. You also need a sense of danger - the NPC should not really stand there looking in one direction, it should have a path that it follows and its gaze should scan for enemies. It should react if it sees you. The bodies shouldn't dissolve into thin air; leave the bodies on the ground, bonus points if they stay where they are. 6:41, the reaction of the NPC is robotic. Have it show us body moment that says "surprised!" to us. 6:45, the slashing is okay...the wounds aren't there, the amount of blood is a but much, let our character get dirty from the blood and dirt. Look at Death Stranding (DS) - take guidance from there. You see how the chars in DS have weight, have senses, communicate with each other, make noise...do that. 6:50, the enemy should be shouting, yelling, giving you commands...hitting a sword with a gun...that is odd behavior. 6:52 when getting hit, the NPC should visibly and audibly show discomfort, fear, etc. 7:05 sequence...blood looks horrible. the NPC's eyes look dead. NPC has no power...dies easily. The other NPC stands there waiting to be activated. 7:12 HUGEEE OPPORTUNITY to have NPC try to intimidate with dialog and say something...be angry...not emotionless.  --------- so, these are just a few things. Not saying you need to get all of these right. I'm saying, if you're looking to set a standard, then SET A STANDARD for not just visuals but also gameplay from Indian devs. You have plenty of talent. Start A/B testing mechanics from other BEST in class game. STEAL from them. do not reinvent. Literally look at mechanics and copy them from the best US IPs. Not saying literally steal but saying take heavy inspiration. They've already done the work for you to figure out how good character movement is...how NPCs should react....how blood should look...how to make it look like that you and the world...and the NPCs have weight...heft. etc...BIG enemies should feel big...lumbering...they should drag heavy things. If your storyline is incredible, then that may carry the gameplay portion. But if you've made it look incredible but the gameplay itself is NOT FUN or realistic...while you've made an effort for it to be hyper realistic...and if your story is also lack luster where it's just an after thought because bunch of visual engineers are making a tech demo essentially...then, you won't get recognition. Ok, lastly, if you want to see how to get respect from the US and other countries, all you need to do is look at Hanumankind. How did he get that much respect? He did it better than what's being done here in the US. That's how you get respect. KEEP THE SCOPE OF THE LENGTH OF THE GAME SHORT, but build something worth playing. Build something which, when we play it...seems like something that we want more of. Build something that will cause american giants to reach out and say "Hey, we wanna buy this IP or license it...or, can you work with us and have your team release a full game?" Good luck. I really really hope that you make the best game India has ever made.

I get it that this is a SOULS LIKE game but try something original. Maybe small mandirs of Hanuman Ji and a lot of our gods from which he medidates and regenerates. I can't tell about the setting but maybe the story is set that way. I really like that you are using the traditional approach by building assets from scracth. That's just as original as one can hope. Striking animation need some work as damage to the enemy is seen but not felt. Parrying is OK but heavy attacks need to be perfected and the damage from them. Dodge is great. I get that this is an alpha footage and a lot of work is incomplete. I hope I am not disappointed.

author: @vinamrajha
text:
REVIEW AS A GAMER:-  As a hardcore gamer who has played almost all top-tier games. I am not sure about what you mean by the term "Super High Quality", as the game is not high quality at all. I was shocked with Intro, the surroundings looked quite realistic but when it comes to actual characters it just looks like two games combined in one. The surrounding seems like from a top tier game while the main character and playable part looks tbh, very Average. The music and sounds are fine. The type of game you chose, the story line felt very outdated, games storylines matters a lot now a days and this doesnt give a reason for me to play. 

Review as Viewer: Now those were my feedback as a gamer, when i see it practically, this is quite commendable to be making a game in just 8 months while having a team of 40 people is no joke. The top games in the industry takes years and years, so congratulations on that. The FPS was not good in the game but i do understand its just a demo of early stage game, so it will be obviously be improved a lot in next couple of months. Hear me out, if possible please use the components of this game and recreate the storyline, something modern, something creative, take your time and if possible ditch this game and make something entirely different, this game is bound to fail with this storyline and characters like these. Get over Mumbai and Slums. 

Will i play? : Answer is Maybe, depends on the price and only bc its been made here and i want to support them. I wont even have a thought of playing it if it wasn‚Äôt bc of that. I dont like the storyline, dont know why but i have seen too many games with the same storyline from India, there is no chance it will get global recognition organically without your personal image being combined. The games are mostly played by Genz and lower but this game isnt modern, not something that attracts me, maybe 30+ age group might give it a go. We need to support this industry but true feedback is required, and i can see the so much of jingoism in the comments, true feedback is not there. India Needs to get over these kind of Storyline bring something different, something that Raji did!

Movements while running look clunky the lack of facial expression takes away the charm although if possible add them but if not at least add some dialogues to the enemies while fighting. also add an indicator to show a cinematic signature move to finish off the enemy when it's on last health I mean for smaller enemies. author: @VioletGOKU
text:
Hi Varun, as an avid gamer and someone eagerly waiting for authentic Indian games all my life, I sincerely want you and this project to succeed, and that's why I'm going to give you honest, reality-driven feedback - 
1.) Typically, a GTA style script where the character fights locals and law enforcement inspires the wrong kind of mentality in youth. Seeing as you have yourself made of lot of educational content in your career, I would encourage you to re-imagine the script that keeps the fun intact but leans more towards morally correct story, and character development focused on education, innovation, and nation-building. You have a great potential opportunity here to distinguish your game by designing quests and campaigns that are educational and fun at the same time for the characters. (Bonus idea - maybe in same game or a different one in the future - there is potential for players to choose different professions and accordingly the gameplay changes)
2.) I understand the need for designing characters as accurately as possible, but given that the religion and caste divide has already reached the peek of toxicity in our country, I would encourage you to refrain from portraying any specific caste/religion from being the villain. For example, the character wielding a gadaa is designed as a Brahmin but categorized as "sankat" by the system. Such things can subtly create strong wrong notions, prejudices and uncalled hatred in the minds of youth. You yourself said that people should be able to carry the memory of a character for lifetime. Well, it's your responsibility that players don't carry a wrongful memory (even if it's unintentional) throughout their lives and hate someone based on their caste. Not to mention the potential for political controversies.
It's clear that a lot of hard work, money, and time has gone into this already. And kudos to you and the team for making it so far. Just be responsible with the actual game script, characters and character development, and you'll have a superhit release right out the gate. Genuinely wishing you and the team success! ü™î‚úå

author: @cozziee92
text:
Good Effort. Some feedback:
1. The protagonist's animation look too much like Black Myth Wukong. Please change that or this will be criticised heavily upon launch.
2. The settings seems modern day Mumbai. Why is the main character using swords?
3. Please work on facial animations a bit. The character models do not show any expressions during combat or parkour.
4. Scale seems to be off, the character models are looking way too large compared to the environment.
5. Something needs to be done about the choppy framerate.
6. This seems like a souls like game hence, more attention needs to be paid towards telegraphng boss attacks. Right now it seems all too simple and predictable.
7. Shrines as checkpoints seem out of place considering the modern day setting.
8. Unreal engine 4? Please do make sure that the final game doesn't ave any shader compilation stutters.
9. The focus on photo realism is too heavy. While this may be a good thing, this will eventually lead to the team ignoring the overall gameplay. Focus more in improving the gameplay loop and make the game more responsive and gameplay more captivating. Graphics can follow later.
10. Please please hire well experienced managers who are good human beings as well. Endevours like this often fail due to incompetent managers with bloated ego.

Having said that, this is a real good effort considering it has been built in India. Please work on the points above and this just might have a fighting chance.

author: @smithpatel9664
text:
While I appreciate the effort behind the quality, the animations and actions feel incomplete. The story is truly the soul of any game, and it needs to be engaging and relatable to resonate with a broader audience. Simply roaming around and eliminating enemies doesn't define a compelling game experience‚Äîtemplates for such designs are readily available on platforms like the Unreal Marketplace. Also, overhyping the product by repeatedly stressing 'high quality' can backfire. It's often better to let the quality speak for itself, as excessive hype might fall flat with audiences. Best of luck refining and polishing the game further!

try to think as a gamer then as person who just want to make high quality game, try to learn from similar successful games, the movement, FX, animations, camera angles, look and feel, colors used to tell the story, ......this is nothing but a honest opinion.

author: @chandan2836
text:
As happy I am for watching what's happening in the video, I still think slum like areas of India shouldn't be in a  game which is trying to reach a greater audience, Sekiro is my favourite game and I immediately recognised where you drew inspiration from from the first instance of Combat showcase, 
as gritty as sekiro is its world is still beautiful to look at (fountain Head palace, Senpu temple, the silver grass field, bhodisattva valley, serpent shrine and even the Dilapidated temple) the world is beautiful not because of photorealistic details, its because of art style of fromsoftware you get the point. 
Yes the visual fidelity of this game is excellent but I don't want to look at makeshift tents and blue tarps and dirty streets,
Especially around 7:42 seeing the shrine placed in an environment like that is not pleasing to look at and no one in their sane mind would disagree,
 I dont wanna see such a great effort going towards the worst aspects of our motherland, is that what we should immortalise in a media like videogames trying to reach a global audience?

I know the whole game is not set in a slum but it's still a part of a story , story of which is inspired by somthing that sacred to us all. I might sound like an angry grifter but I just wanna see great things coming out of us,
 Indians tend to settle for mediocre things despite having better minds on said job

one more thing which absolutely troubled me by seeing all the amazing work done on visual aspect is Performance 19:45 you finally mentioned it but called it a joke just because it raises too many things to worry about, I'd like to remind you of cyberpunk, fallout 76 and No man's sky on its release dates, they failed miserably because of poor optimization and it alienated majority of the gamers from those games despite the hype so please don't take performance and optimization lightly.
You mentioned at the end  how important it is to reach bigger audiences which brings me great Joy that someone is aiming higher than just local audience 
As a very passionate gamer who likes slow paced story driven games like Hellblade, Red dead, the last of us and some occasional combat experiences like sekiro, Dead cells, witcher. I really love the focus points of this game being the combat ,story and the progression 
I really wish the best for your game!

author: @mayukh_
text:
Honest review!

What was good:

1. Scene/world generation. 
2. Tech that was onboarded 
3. Sheer hardwork that you guys have put 

What can improve:
1. More realistic character movements
2. More detailing with ray tracing in complex scenes. 
3. Better storytelling 

What was bad:
1. Unnecessary touch of religion. This seems like a clickbait. We have a lot more pressing issues in India
2. Loose the touch of INDIA INDIA, oh it‚Äôs made in Indja. No one cares if it is made in India or Japan or US. The only thing that makes sense is how wonderfully you executed it.

author: @priyanshudwibedy
text:
Since this is an early alpha .I have some recommendations, hope you u will look through it:

-- I know you are taking inspiration from Black myth wukong, Dark Souls and sekiro(parry) . But the environment doesn't fit well , the dusty Screenshot of building you presented looked better than the character fighting i.e during the motion of character its not feeling that they are connecting (I don't know how to say this but this is how it felt).
--The enemies didn't feel THREATENING, its like they waiting too long, THEY SHOULD WAIT BUT IT FELT TOO LONG AND WEAK (you know what i mean right ,Eg: sekiro common enemies would fuck you up but here it felt like they can't do anything unless you are distracted and have not paused the game)
--Make the Visuals look like top view of city you showed in the pictures
--The SANKAT word when an Undodgeable attack comes looks too big and distracting please make it smaller. (Its a small nitpick but If you see this please consider)

I hope the game is fun for both casual and hardcore gamers, and i hope you all the best (I like difficult but fair games, and it looks like a game i will love ).

author: @_.hrsht._
text:
One suggestion on the unlesshing of Avatar. 

I'd say, do it in certain levels. Like the form you showed while our MC was fighting that gigantic man is too over powered. For many people it might look a bit weird too. 

What can be done is, let's make 4-5 levels of transformation with power levels in ascending order. 
Eg. 
1) Slight color change and two bracelets appearing on both of his hands.
(This will be for fighting tougher individual opponents) 

2) A tiara type thing (which was shown in the video) appears oh his head and a locket appears. (His colour would remain the same as level 1) 

3) His shirt Vanishes and a few more ornaments appear. The colour changes completely. (This will be the most powerful form which he can control) 

4) The final form, 
(basically the one you showed entirely in the video) 
which he'll never be able to control properly, for that he'll have to undergo a lot of psychological, philosophical and mental training. 
All the other forms will just be an incomplete invocation/manifestation of the final form. 

Just a suggestion tho‚ù§
Keep up the good work.
Can't express my happiness towards the creative work.‚ù§

author: @milanvanik5247
text:
Story comes first,
Controls/Mechanics comes second,
Graphics comes third.

The NPC fights didn't felt smooth, but as the boss arrived it went good. Here also the difficulty seem to be good he was really stopping us to get close and attack. 

when i saw the deathblow red dot. i started to think isn't there any way to show this in Indian way like chakra point or anything.  You can take some move set and twist it according to game like Mikri counter it feels great when using it.

anyway the main reason for this comment was the smoothness of movement. There are games where the movement flows like a wave and there are games which just doesn't feel like playing because of controls. I can't really explain but if i have to put it into words, I could say Imagine switching direction from going top left to top right, in bad controls it feels like a quick sharp turn and also after switching direction the player walks in a straight line like its little rigid on its movement. In good games the corners take smooth curvy switch. 

By The Way Sekiro is my Favourite Game üòâ‚ù§

author: @harrykurakula6390
text:
The only reason why there were no Indian made AAA Quality games till now is there's no market for that in India..An average Indian can't buy a PlayStation / PC to play games.. Major market is mobile gaming..

So, I really want you guys to focus on foreign markets.. "MAKE AN INDIAN MADE GAME FOR FOREIGN MARKET"
Raji is the only game that somewhat succeeded in this

If you make this game targeting Indian audience, then you will be ultimately forced to port this to mobile which makes all the real high quality photogrammetry just a waste of time and resources.. Also Indians are only used to MMO gaming thanks to PUBG but not much to RPGs

So, I request Varun and team to focus on West and promote this for West, like Wukong and other games..
This has the potential. Forget about India. There is a huge market for Indian made stuff in the West. RRR is a great example of that. West got tired of their products. They want to try new cultures. So, keep it culture appropriate and market for the West..

feedback - The game and mechanics are looking great but lacks distinction to attract large audience is what I feel.. I believe that part is where this footage ended. So, I guess there will be distinction.. For the final product, do some distinct color grade in the post process volume and kindly avoid that typical Unreal look..

Congrats and All the bestüëèüëèüëè
Salute to whatever you guys accomplished till now. This is no easy task ü´°

author: @Hannibalhacks-g4m
text: Can't believe i was hooked till the end. Awesome work brother. The graphics really looks like built by those foreign gaming giants. But as a gamer, I feel it looks rushed. The story feels a bit disconnected from reality üòÖ (not criticizing). Just want you to know, the story is a very important aspect of the game. And with all the woke garbage modern gaming companies are promoting, it feels like a breathe of fresh air and reminisced us about our childhoold. Games like Prince of persia, Farcry, Crisis, Lara Croft etc. did leave a mark on me. After all, these just games. No man, people will remember. Please take some more time. I'm requesting you to take your time, work on the story, the gameplay could be improved. This has a lot potential and maybe a start for something bigger. At least an Indian is trying to represent our history, culture through a creation instead of a foreign company. I'm proud of you and your team. GG.

author: @spelgrafiken
text:
10:32 do not compare it with AAA game, at the end whatever you make AAA game, 2d game or 3d game or ultra realistic graphic game, at the end it comes to fun. Even if you build 2d game and it is fun to play and you enjoy it better than any AAA game, so that's a win. Do not compete , focus on the fun element. I have played all types of game, what I look in any game is the fun element, does not matter it is AAA or any platform.
So please do not fall into the comparison trap, just focus on fun element. I am telling this all according to a player perspective, I maybe wrong according to game developer perspective , but we gamers want fun remember that.

text:
Recommendations: The animation feels a little stiff. I think you guys are using a single attack animation for the initial strikes. I‚Äôd recommend creating 2‚Äì3 slightly varied attack animations (same swing and final pose, just different angles or timing) to reduce stiffness and make it feel more dynamic and authentic.

Also, I‚Äôm curious about the voice acting. I didn‚Äôt hear any in this clip‚Äîjust basic growls and grunts. I assume that‚Äôs just a placeholder until the full release, but if not, please consider this as constructive feedback. Adding proper voice lines would really enhance the experience.

author: @hanumant._.thite0
text:
The game looks great, from the graphics to interesting 3d models taken from the real world of slum colonies (I love the concept), to the characters' appearance and the background architecture (random buildings like in our country). It has real potential to be big because of its authenticity. I just have one constructive criticism or input (if it matters): there is no backstory or character explanation in the position they are in, the get-up, and the reason for their powers. The Explanation would be awesome even in trailer form or cutscenes. So far, it just seems like a typical indian superhero like Hero (with the ring), Shiktiman, etc. Who are cool but seems a little outdated way to explain a hero's origin and reason for powers. It seems you are tapping into the mythical godly characters like Shiva or Krishna, but please make it its own genuine thing if that makes sense.
A genuine and unique story with original and authentic characters and world-building (which you have built in some sense, story-wise). The STORY is the Heart of this kind of project, be it a Movie, TV show, or game.
I am looking forward to seeing whatflavor you givee it and what world-building and character stories you create around it.

author: @Graveness4920
text:
Although I don‚Äôt particularly like your presentation style, I‚Äôm giving you another chance. The game looks excellent, especially considering it is still in its early phase of development. I‚Äôm glad that India has genuine risk-takers like you rather than just ‚Äúkeyboard warriors‚Äù like myself.

I also want to share a piece of advice: in software development, it‚Äôs a good practice to ask an engineer for an estimate and then double it for planning purposes but please don‚Äôt mention this trick to the engineer.

One concern I have about the video is the claim that the game is 60% complete in 10 months. Honestly, that isn‚Äôt a realistic timeline for game development; it usually takes at least 2 to 3 years.

That said, you have an amazing and promising team. Thanks for the introduction!

author: @KrishNahBro
text:
Superb! Finally, an Indian game that takes healthy inspiration from Indian culture without being completely dependent on it! After watching the clip, I‚Äôm genuinely amazed.

Varun, I hope you read this comment. I just want to say that I‚Äôve never bought a game before, but I will 100% buy yours.

I only have a few requests, and I hope you‚Äôll consider them. Graphics aren‚Äôt everything‚Äîwhat truly matters is a good story, solid mechanics, and overall gameplay. I understand there are many challenges for a beginner-level studio like yours (such as adding facial expressions), but I really appreciate the effort you‚Äôre putting in.

If you‚Äôve read this far, I just want to add:
Don‚Äôt take on unnecessary pressure.
Don‚Äôt sell lies.
Don‚Äôt do false promotions.
Just be yourself, and success will follow.

Godspeed, Varun!

Needs polish. Animation, vfx, asset quality is at or pre 2015 levels. A small trial didn't have to be this expensive. You could have done a single neighborhood first, refined/improved on it and then decided if you were ready to sink the resources.
If you think global audience is going to pay to play this game, I hope you re-evaluate your ego. A 'great game from India' doesn't have to strive for next gen photogrammetry or even be about India. It has to be a good game first. 
But it's usually only up from rock-bottom so good luck with your game project.

author: @Abhishek_78
text:
Yes I used AI to reframe my original comment my brain has forgotten reading comprehension :(

Hi Varun, Project 11A looks incredibly promising! The discussion around the game‚Äôs visuals and asset creation was impressive, and it‚Äôs clear there‚Äôs a lot of high-quality work going into the design. 
That said, some elements could use a bit more polish‚Äîparticularly the graphics, where things like the grass feel slightly off, though it‚Äôs hard to pinpoint exactly why.

It seems like a lot of focus has been on the game‚Äôs aesthetics, which look stunning, but I‚Äôm really hoping the gameplay matches that standard. 
From the demo, the combat appeared a bit straightforward; for example, strafing was enough to dodge the boss‚Äôs attacks. I‚Äôm curious about the game‚Äôs target audience. 
Is it aimed at Soulslike players (e.g., Elden Ring, Lies of P) who crave deep, challenging mechanics, or is it leaning more toward a broader action game style (e.g., God of War)?

For serious gamers, especially FromSoftware fans, gameplay mechanics and difficulty balance are often more important than visuals. 
If Project 11A is targeting the Soulslike crowd, I hope the final product delivers a fair but punishing difficulty curve with rewarding mechanics. 
It‚Äôs not entirely clear yet how much of the Soulslike philosophy will shape the game or if it‚Äôs going for a more accessible action vibe, but I‚Äôm excited to see where it lands!

author: @Winkie_Winx
text:
I have always said this that India needs to start building an ecosystem of tech infra of their own rather than depending on global following the trend blindly. Finally someone has taken the initiative, building a huge library of scans and that too of such large volumes, these processes surely does take time but once done, the outcomes will always blow your mind, and its clearly visible in the video, the high quality 3D assets, are just WOW!! Incredible job guys. High and Best Quality should be the north metric of any such product if you are aiming for long run. 

Kudos to AEOS team and to you Varun! Looking forward for more exciting updates.

author: @JohnDoe-qj3iv
text:
Amazing work man. I really appreciate you getting into the depths of the technology which you have used for the game. But few criticisms:

1.) The combat weirdly feels too slow and heavy for some reason, maybe it's just the framerate. Keep in mind that for gameplay like Sekiro you would need at the least 60fps.. 

2.) Character design feels a bit uninspired 

3.) The Map and the environment is a bit too real, in the sense it doesn't have that ethereal more dramatic look that I would expect from a game, in short it looks realistic not artistic, no offense to the artist involved lol... 
 
4.) Something that you would need to keep in mind is that most people who will be trying this game i.e. the Indian people, they are usually not using super-high end system, and seeing the in-game framerate makes me kind of worried.. 

I am sure you would there is still a lot of work to do, but please keep in mind that chances of creating games a financially successful game is still 50-50. Take a look at Bethesda or Ubisoft.. To create something good it doesn't need to be unique but it needs to be super-refined either in terms of mechanics, story-telling or gameplay loop just pick one or two and you'd be golden!

But however it goes, I'll be rooting for you guys success!

author: @segoul7725
text:
Hi! I really love what you and your team are doing, and I really respect the steps taken by you guys in the Indian Game development industry. I do have some feedback, as I want this project to actually be a success even worldwide.

I would strongly suggest you focus more on game feel, as judging from the little gameplay trailer shown in the video, the gameplay (especially the game feel/feedback) seems lacking in some aspects. The souls-like gameplay does feel slightly out of place in a very modern-looking environment. It doesn't feel connected enough. One of the reasons may be because of the very realistic-looking graphics do not fit in place with the gameplay, or the lack of player feedback. Game feel is a really important factor in a game, even more so than how realistic the graphics are. There are a ton of examples of great, successful games having very basic graphics but still very fun, and if I'm gonna be completely honest, the game (of course, only judging from the small gameplay in the video) doesn't look that fun to play.

Don't get me wrong, I'm not hating on this. In fact, I'm really excited about this as I'm also an aspiring game developer from India, currently working on a game of mine as well. I'm saying this BECAUSE I want this to be a success.

Another feedback I would like to give is to have play tests with people who aren't emotionally connected to this project (which is also suggested by some other comments), as people who are connected to the project will have biases.

I do expect many fixes and improvements in the future, as I'm assuming this project, though 60-70% done as said by you in the video, is still in the early stages where there are lots of minor fixes and polishing to be done, and I will be keeping myself up-to-date on this project.

I would love to give more constructive and detailed feedback on this, but it's 3 a.m. while I'm writing this, and so I should probably sleep...

author: @varunprakash5
text:
I‚Äôm thrilled that individuals like you think big, make bold bets and yet adhere to traditional methods in some areas of your craft to achieve perfection and meticulous attention to detail.

The gameplay looks soo good, never has this super high quality been achieved in our country. And you didn‚Äôt just leave it to Unreal to do the magic.

It‚Äôs easy to repurpose existing assets, but to build from scratch - Blocking a whole freakin‚Äô town - and with that level of detailing and perfection is something legends do!

And to pursue bootstrapping takes guts to take on such a massive risk. 

The next mountain in this journey would be distribution, and I know you all will ace that too.

Ive worked in large-ultra large companies marketing bleeding edge tech. Throughout my career, I‚Äôve encountered numerous agencies, particularly in the marketing sector, that followed the crowd and were solely driven by financial gain, without making significant contributions to our country. I was never satisfied working with most of them for the high-end tech work I did in my time (some of which has reached the Central Government and international levels, being endorsed by the Prime Minister and the Minister of IT).

Now, I‚Äôve realised that Aeos (and even 100x, where I‚Äôm a student) is not just another agency; it‚Äôs a vision and a future being actively realised! It‚Äôs a bright future for our country, constructed by driven intellectuals.

I‚Äôve shared this message with Lt Col Sandeep Sir and I share this with you too.

I‚Äôm now going to spread the word about your work and celebrate your achievements!

Shine on ‚ú® We‚Äôre rooting for you üôå

author: @DaoistYeashikAli
text:
First of all congratulations and thank you. I just have some suggestions:
i) Try to make combat more viceral and put more weight/punch to it by focusing on hitboxes and sound fx (can take inspiration for ghost of tsushima and gears)
ii) avoid too much slo mo scenes and those weird poses during combat.
iii) I am hoping good quality writing for you guys, no matter how good gameplay and visuals are, without good narrative, lore and worldbuilding it will feel shallow. (can take inspiration from Witcher 3, BG3 and KCD)
iv) Don't put Ubisoft style fetch quests and ? marks to fill the map. Put quality side contents on per with main quests. Quality over quantity. (inspiration again from Witcher 3, Oblivion, KCD, Cyberpunk, New vegas)

author: @davesohamm
text:
Look man, I don't want to discourage or anything. But here's what's going to happen -
you made some custom 3D presets, and made a physics and logic with a mixture 2-3 studios like Rockstar and Ubisoft. Indian gamers will go crazy over this gameplay. But the uniqueness, individual storyline and the feeling of a game will be missing forever. Every game has a soul, otherwise this will be nothing more than just like MOD to any game. People will start commenting "I have never seen something like that" OR "The indian gaming scene is changing" for some time, but we all know what is the reality my man. These will be the first people to give curses to the game after the beta release, trust me. They don't care about the budgets, the marketing, the level designing, storylining, version updates or anything. We all have seen what happened to mumbai gullies. For one time, we can praise Raji here. But did indians really paid for that game? No. They do not pay for games like that. They want an Indian GTA... that's their ultimate dream, they don't see anything far from that. If you think this project could go further, definitely work on it. But don't forget that you are making just A GAME. You are making no GTA, no Far Cry, no Call Of Duty. It's a game, and it should have it's own soul. They criticized Fauji, because they wanted PUBG. They criticized Mumbai Gullies, because they expected GTA. Do not repeat the same mistake again after looking at the initial positive response. You will need heavy feedback from people who you can't find in comments. Think about it. I know this might sound triggering to some of the people here, but I am expecting a mature audience reaction, other than that my best wishes are with you. Come on guys, show the world that we are not just a tinkering lab, we can create something on our own! Let's not make cheap copies of big titles, this is time to get dirty with some real business.

author: @SandeepJadam
text: In your video, you discussed game assets like art, animation, and coding, but you didn‚Äôt mention game designers or level designers. A game isn‚Äôt just about realistic art or making characters move and fight‚Äîgameplay is the most important aspect. From what I saw in the video, the gameplay didn‚Äôt stand out to me. In India, VFX and art are top-notch, but there are very few skilled game designers. I hope you have a good game designer on your team, though it wasn‚Äôt highlighted in the video. The gameplay shown didn‚Äôt feel engaging to me. These are my personal views, and I mean no offense. I‚Äôm learning game design and level design myself, which is why these thoughts came to mind.

author: @mnomprakash
text:
This is Sekiro! Would have liked to see original mechanics as well, while the visual and setting of the story definitely feel original. The posture meter that depletes, the deathblow indicator and deathblow animation, the walking animation, the 'Sankat' that pops up just like the Kenji in Sekiro, the shrines - too many items borrowed from a single game. 
Great attempt and more power to you though as this is not an easy industry! Will always encourage an Indian game studio that is aspiring to make AAA games.

author: @hamzahgamedev
text:
The level of detail is absolutely incredible and I loved every second of what I saw. Huge congratulations on everything you‚Äôve achieved so far and I truly hope this is just the beginning of an amazing journey ahead!

That said, I found myself a bit confused about the overall setting of the game. The mix of swordplay with enemies wielding guns, followed by a larger boss carrying a gada, left me unsure of the world you‚Äôre trying to build. The equipment selection/save area, designed like a small shrine or temple, also felt slightly out of place compared to the rest of the environment.

Maybe a bit more context or environmental storytelling could help tie everything together and give players a clearer sense of the game‚Äôs universe. Still, super impressive work, and I‚Äôm excited to see where this goes next!

author: @DocPrakhar
text:
Feedback: Looks very cool. I do expect some improvements though. The look of Typical India city is perfectly seen. Some inputs from me:
1. Make the blood spill from Asuras be a different colour than human - black will be nice.
2. More special effects needed on the Gada hit from the boss - especially when he hits the ground, it should create an earthquake, or make the earth crack up. The Tractor and Thela could fly off due to the impact.
3. Make the Sankat a little bit smaller. Make health bars a bit larger. (It looks like you took inspiration from Spidey sense).
4. I hope it supports upto 120 fps in the future. DLSS support will be nice.
5. If you have to hire a really good storywriter and editor because story is most important part of such a game. Brahmastra spent so much on graphics but story was dogs**t. Impressing international audience requires a very nuanced story. Especially one with twists. Ramayana is a great epic and story but it lacks the spiciness. Mahabharat though is full of spicy.
6. I hope there are more slo mo special moves like the protagonist did there to dodge.
7. A few textures especially on characters could be little bit more detailed. Environment is perfect imo. The necklace on boss looks fake and floating in air. 
8. Hire a martial artist if you haven't already for the moves, makes a huge difference.
9. Make the protagonist's weapon a bit larger.
10. More people (Spectators watching you fight) and more interactions with environment will be nice. It will be difficult to give them actions or emotions. Like they could be anxious if you get injured, or happy when you hit them.
11. Gameplay looks very slow. I see so many elements inspired by Wukong, but gameplay is much slower here. You'll need to do drastic changes if you want to make gameplay feel faster.
12. Needs a lot of Dialogue. I suggest you hire someone for that too. The character must feel very real. Some humour, som serious, some sad cut scenes or events.

I'm extremely excited for the game. Will definitely buy it. I want to see Aeos become as big as Tencent, Rockstar, Epic, Riot & EA. I'm very very thankful. You and your team have got that Risk taking ability that we say is lacking in India. Even Wukong took $42 million to develop, which is already very cheap forAAA (Cyberpunk cost more than 10 times that). I'm guessing you're working with even smaller amount, so it's a huge challenge. I wish you the best of Luck

author: @anushchandrashetty
text:
Great CGI!! But since it is an early build, please allow me to play the devil's advocate (coz I really want this game to be the definition of perfection):

1. When the player slashes the NPCs, there is no visible wounds or blood stains spilled on the ground. Even on their clothes or the player's clothes!! Without inflicted wounds and tarnishes on the clothes, it seems to be just an objective and not an actual battle.
2. Similarly, when the blood splashes on to the player, there are no visible stains either on his clothes or swords(maybe the sword can be ignored, as such fine detailing may not be visible even in 4K). We can have these blood stains on the player and reset them when the player heals near the shrine so that the clothes don't seem bloody all the time.
3. The assets on Kshudita asura are not on his body, they seem to float (example the neck gold ornaments). Sometimes they seem to disappear and appear frequently as well when the asura is fighting the player.

author: @svm6683
text:
My Honest Take (Hope You Consider These Points):

First of all, huge kudos to you guys for this god-tier work. Seriously, hats off. But I hope you‚Äôre considering the following points‚Äîjust my honest thoughts after watching the trailer:

1. The Game Being Your First Release:
This is your debut title, so it has to be a killer. What usually happens in India is that due to lack of funding, the first game from a new studio often falls short. It doesn't match the quality of already established international companies, and the usual justification becomes: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre new, we‚Äôre small, we don‚Äôt have enough funds, what do you expect?‚Äù
But for gamers‚Äîthese excuses don‚Äôt really fly.
They want the best of the best‚Äîstory mode, graphics, gameplay, sound design‚Äîeverything needs to hit the current benchmark. You can't use ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre just starting out‚Äù as a reason for a downgrade in all aspects and hope that things will improve later. There‚Äôs no space for that anymore.
So I hope you guys are keeping this in mind.


2. Indian Representation & Personal Mental Shift:
Now this might be personal, but I felt it strongly. You‚Äôve done an amazing job trying to represent India‚Äîthe cities, the people, weapons, clothes, everything.
But here‚Äôs the thing: We‚Äôve been playing games from smaller US-based and other global studios for years. And there‚Äôs a certain ‚Äúmental shift‚Äù that happens when I see an Indian game attempting this scale.
Like, when I saw that overweight villain with the weapon, something felt... off. Can‚Äôt really explain it, but it gave me a weird vibe. Maybe it‚Äôs just because we‚Äôre not used to seeing such characters in high-budget, polished form. It might take time to fully accept it‚Äîbut yeah, it struck me. Hope you get the point I‚Äôm trying to make.


3. Open World Demands Perfection:
You guys are making an open-world game‚Äîand in that case, nothing can be compromised.
The initial cinematic shots you showed were insanely good. For the first time, it genuinely felt like an Indian studio is doing something exceptional.
But the moment the actual gameplay started, my brain automatically reset expectations. Probably because we already have benchmarks for what gameplay, graphics, sound, etc., should look and feel like.
So while the cinematic shots were jaw-dropping, the gameplay brought me back to ‚ÄúOkay, this looks decent, but not mind-blowing.‚Äù That contrast hit hard.

author: @AbhayKumar-ln2ri
text:
You guys really did an amazing job. I truly want to appreciate the effort. However, with over 12 years of gaming experience since the early 2010s, I‚Äôve seen better character movement and even blood splashes and shadows in not so heavy games like Prince of Persia and Assassin‚Äôs Creed Liberation or Black Flag,etc.
The fight scenes also felt quite unrealistic. For example, when the giant man with the gada hit the sword, the boy‚Äôs body reaction could‚Äôve been more impactful. Also, how come there wasn‚Äôt any conversation between them?

That said, the map and the village shown in the game look absolutely amazing. A huge round of applause for this amazing work. I hope I get a chance to work with you guys some day.
